The report, known as Project PRITCO (Productivity of IT costs) , found that DSS would have employed an additional 29,000 staff were it not for its IT systems. The $2 billion spent on IT over the last 13 years was found to be offset by $6.6 billion in staff costs that have been avoided. An additional $2.5 billion was saved as a result of other IT initiatives, including data matching, fraud prevention and direct credits. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer the minister to his media release of 31 May in relation to the white paper on sustainable energy. I ask: if the minister is truly committed to the development of a policy on sustainable energy, why has he provided disproportionate representation on the ministerial and business round table to the fossil fuel based electricity supply and generation sectors in comparison with representatives of the sustainable energy sector, such as those in energy efficiency and electricity distribution? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is truly committed to the development of a sustainable energy policy. That is why, in accordance with the government's election policy, I announced the process last month, as you referred to in the press release, to formulate a white paper on sustainable energy policy for Australia. I have formulated the presentation of the round table and the associated forum to ensure there is a balanced policy developed which is in the country's best interest.

As you will appreciate, for every interest to be represented on the round table and the forum would make the bodies too large to be effective. The sustainable energy sector will be represented on the round table through a representative of its choice and the forum will include three representatives of that sector. In fact, I think they are the three representatives in Australia.

PARA.BREAK: The senator refers to electricity distribution and I believe this interest is adequately represented on both the round table and the forum through the involvement of the Electri city Supply Association whose membership includes both generators and distributors. I might add that groups other than in sustainable energy sector have also approached me, as you would expect, for enlarged representation on the round table and/or the forum. I do not want either body to become unmanageably large.

ANSWER.PARA: The energy policy forum is the key body for the development of the white paper. A wide group of stakeholder organisations have been invited to take part in the forum and, as I indicated, three of those are the three sustainable energy groups.

The ministerial and business round table is a body for ongoing consultation with industry on energy policy. While the white paper will be an important early task for the round table, it will have a continuing role. The current membership of the ministerial and business round table is adequate to provide a forum for discussion of the business interests—the purpose for which the round table is being established.

Energy efficiency will be a fundamental part of the white paper and the proposed membership of the round table and the forum will see that it is treated as an integrated part of energy policy. It would be inefficient to allow this important part of energy policy to be treated as a series of sectional interests. The round table is being convened as representing business and the forum as representing principal stakeholder organisations and neither is intended to be an expert group.

In addition to the round table and the forum, all interested parties will have the opportunity to input to the process. A green paper will be published identifying issues and seeking comment from all interested members of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Considering the forum and the ministerial and business round table was for the sustainable energy industry, I was wondering what the minister understood to be the role of the non‐sustainable energy industry—the Australian Coal Association, the Australian Gas Association, the Australian Institute of Petroleum, the Australian explor ation companies, the Minerals Council of Australia, and so on. Does the minister understand what sustainable energy is and could he please provide us with a definition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts did not listen to what I had to say. I said that there was to be a broad ranging green paper followed by a white paper that would cover the whole gamut of energy in Australia for the next 25 years. This is one of the few countries in the world that has not done that. It covers the whole aspect—demand, supply, energy efficiency, usage and feasible alternate forms of energy.

ANSWER.PARA: Someone said the other day that there was a great description of Greens in Italy. They were called tomatoes because they were green when they were young and red when they were old. Let me say to you that you are seeing reds under beds. This is a sustainable energy policy. Just because my press release did not refer to the round table and the energy policy using the same words you have become highly suspicious. You are wrong to be suspicious because it does cover the whole aspect of energy for the next 25 years. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Is it a fact that a recent study into individual workplace agreements in Western Australia reveals that more and more agreements require an employee to produce a medical certificate even for one day's absence due to illness? If this trend is repeated across Australia under the government's industrial relations reforms, what will be the cost to the Commonwealth government, either through Medicare or otherwise?

—First of all, I think that question ought to be more correctly referred to the Minister for Industrial Relations. So far as the costs are concerned, what the senator is trying to ask is: what is going to be the impact on the cost structure of this country of allowing the continuation of a whole range of labour practices that have added to the cost structure of this nation over many years, that has made Australia uncompetitive?

BREAK.PARA: This government is all about trying to reform the workplace practices in this country that benefit both employer and employee in producing greater productivity, higher living standards for all Australians and a better life for us all. So far as the specific question is concerned, whether there is a cost that can be ascertained on that is something I will have a look at. If I have anything to add, I will come back to you.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator MICHAEL BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer the minister to yesterday's question about sales tax by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Faulkner, when he asked you:

QUESTION.PARA: Why did you also mislead the Senate when you stated, `The Treasurer's first announcement was an offer made to the states.'
Minister, do you agree with Senator Faulkner's assertion or was it in fact Senator Faulkner who misled the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Baume for a very important question indeed. Yesterday, as Senator Baume said, Senator Faulkner, the failed former minister for the environment, alleged that I had misled the Senate when I said in this place on 17 June that the Treasurer's first announcement about sales tax on Commonwealth, state, territory and local government vehicles, which was made on 11 June, was an offer made to the states. He said that I misled the Senate. It was not me; it was Senator Faulkner who misled the Senate on this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: If Senator Faulkner had taken the time or if he had the wit to read all of the Treasurer's statement of 11 June and the accompanying transcript of his press conference, which was an integral part of it, he would have seen that the Treasurer said, first of all in the press statement, which Senator Faulkner misquoted:
The Government has taken this decision in the context of the Premiers' Conference and Council of Australian Governments meeting later this week.

The decision to remove sales tax exemptions is an integral part of the Commonwealth's offer document sent to the States and Territories today. Removal of the sales tax exemptions is a condition of the Commonwealth's general offer on financial assistance grants. The Commonwealth will seek agreement to the offer as a whole at the Premiers' Conference.

In his press conference at the same time as releasing the announcement, the Treasurer elaborated still further on that. He repeated that the sales tax decision was an integral part of the offer to the states and territories. He went on to say:

That offer is an offer to maintain the real per capita guarantee to the states. It is, however, conditional on an acceptance of susceptibility of state governments to the wholesale sales tax. It is a conditional offer. Let me make it clear that if it were not for the application of the wholesale sales tax or, being more precise, the withdrawal of the exemption in relation to wholesale sales tax, the Commonwealth would not be in a position to make the real per capita guarantee it has made in relation to financial assistance grants.
He went on to say:
I make it entirely clear that the real per capita guarantee could only be offered on the basis that the unfair exemption is removed.
Then he went on to say:
If the states put to us that they would prefer the unfair exemption to remain and give away the real per capita guarantee, we will entertain that proposal from them.

It is absolutely a black and white case, if ever there was one, of Senator Faulkner having misled the Senate again on a very important matter, just as he did in his former role as environment minister in the Keating government when he narrowly escaped censure in this place for gross incompetence of his ministerial responsibilities.

It is absolutely clear that my statement in the Senate on 17 June was totally correct. It is equally clear that Senator Faulkner's assertion in the Senate yesterday was totally incorrect. I call upon Senator Faulkner to have the decency and perhaps the guts to apologise to the Senate and to me for his disgraceful and wilful misleading of the Senate yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. From what you have just said, if the statement which was made on 11 June was an offer and not an announcement, why did the seven days start from that date? Is it in fact that the first advice you got from the taxation commissioner was correct? If what you say today now is the fact, was the taxation commissioner wrong yesterday in saying that the seven days started from the 11th?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not repeat all of what I said to Senator Baume, but what I will say is that, on 11 June, the government made a decision in relation to sales tax which was an integral part of the offer to the states.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I know the Senate is very interested in Senator Short's explanation on this. The clock has been set to one minute. We would want to hear a full four-minute explanation from Senator Short.
—We will set the clock correctly.
—I have finished my answer. I have nothing more to add to what I said to Senator Wheelwright.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, take your seat. Stop the clock. We will await some silence. I call Senator Short.
—Nothing that Labor can say—
—You fool!
—Order! Senator Faulkner!

—Nothing that Labor can say can deny the fact that Senator Faulkner yesterday deliberately and wilfully misled the Senate and today appears to be completely refusing to have the guts to apologise for what he did. So far as Senator Wheelwright's question is concerned, I repeat to Senator Wheelwright—soon to be Mr Wheelwright—that the decision in relation to the sales tax was, as the Treasurer said on 11 June, an integral part of the overall offer to the states. That is very clear, and the inference that you have drawn from that is absolutely and totally incorrect.

—Before I call Senator Bell, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of a Commonwealth Parliamentary Association study group. The group includes members of the parliaments of Cook Islands, Niue and Vanuatu. On behalf of honourable senators I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and hope that your stay here will be productive and rewarding—and a little enlightening, although I doubt it.
—I call Senator Bell.
—Mr President, my question is—
—Do you want an Assistant Treasurer over there?
—You are so rude.
—Order! Stop the clock again. We will wait for silence. I call Senator Bell.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. Do you agree with former coalition environment spokesperson Senator Rod Kemp who, in March 1995, said that the coalition would look at tax breaks to promote environmentally sound performance by industry; that developing countries should be subjected to tougher greenhouse restrictions; and that there should be a conditional ban on woodchip exports? If you do agree with Senator Kemp, what sorts of tax breaks will you be introducing? Which tougher greenhouse restrictions will you be recommending, and for which countries? And when will you be banning woodchip exports? If you do not agree with Senator Kemp, when and why did you change coalition policy?

—I agree with everything Senator Kemp says. Yes, in relation to greenhouse gases, we do believe that developing countries should play their role. We are almost to the stage, in the international community, where greenhouse gases produced by developing countries will exceed those produced by developed countries. If you are interested in a better global outcome, then it logically follows that you would like to see developing countries included within the formula. It is one of the things on which I agreed with the former minister for the environment. I would have thought you ought to as well. You are an astonishing lot over there, you Australian Democrats, I must say. The most rapid increases in greenhouse gases are occurring in the developing world. You look at what is happening in China and India and say that it is irrelevant. When we say they should play their part as well, you say, `We're not interested in that.' You have become totally illogical.
—Always! Always!
—Order!
—We are wanting to invest $300 million in natural vegetation.
—Oh! Oh! Ha, ha!

—You laugh at it. One way in which Australia can contribute to a better greenhouse outcome is to spend $300 million on native vegetation, on revegetation. You know that. But what happens? We bring you the chance to support it and you say, `No, we're not interested.' Now you come in here today and say that you are not interested in developing countries playing a role as well. You are totally ingenuous. You have no interest in the environment at all. In relation to woodchips—
—This is the way you persuade them to vote for you, is it, Robert?

—I am trying to knock some sense into their heads, to be quite honest. In relation to woodchips, you heard from Senator Parer earlier that the issue of woodchip regulations is under consideration, and an announcement will be made in due course.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that attempt, but I did not get an answer to the question. What I heard was the usual diatribe, which was an attack on our party, rather than answering the simple question: which tax breaks will you be recommending for those industries which promote environmentally sound performance? You ignored that one conveniently, probably because that meant some sort of budgetary commitment—a commitment to the environment from the budget—rather than an ex‐budget thing, which is what you are promoting Telstra as. So why have you changed from this budgetary commitment, which was suggested by Senator Kemp, to this offside sort of arrangement for Telstra? We don't see, for example, Defence being funded ex‐budget in the way that you are proposing for the environment.

—`Offside'? `Why did we change our policy?', he said. I would have thought we could not have made it clearer at the election that our intention was to sell one-third of Telstra and use $1 billion from the proceeds of that sale to reinvest in Australia's natural heritage. Are you suggesting that we did not put that to the Australian people? Are you suggesting that we are not offering the people of Australia the chance of the largest re‐investment in our natural capital in the history of this country? Why won't you be a party to it?
—Why isn't it in the budget?

—That is your answer, isn't it? Put up taxes or borrow more. That is the legacy we inherited from you: put up taxes or borrow more to fund all the national needs. That is why we have three‐quarters of a million Australians out of work. That is not our preferred way. Our preferred way is to produce a capital fund which will be outside the budgetary process in the future. It is a great advantage for the environment.(Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment. Minister, noting the information you gave to the Leader of the National Party in the Senate, Senator Boswell, earlier in question time, I ask: can you now explain to the Senate why you have agreed to allow the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to be the sole administrator of the $195 million allocated to the Murray‐Darling 2001 project and the national land and water resources audit? And, minister, why is it that only one of the five capital projects announced in your environment policy is to be administered by the department of the environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not correct, for a start. If the extra funding for the Murray‐Darling were to be administered by the department of primary industry, that should not surprise you because, under your regime, the existing funding was administered by the department of primary industries. What are you coming in here and suggesting now?

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Stop the clock. We will wait for some silence. I now call Senator Faulkner.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My supplementary question is this: now that the government has decided that the environment department would be responsible for, at the most, only 46 per cent of the natural heritage trust funds, aren't you the one and only minister in the government to have been comprehensively rolled by Senator Boswell and the National Party?

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Hold the clock again. I now call Senator Hill.

—I take it Senator Faulkner is now agreeing with what I said about the Murray‐Darling. He is conceding the first point. The second point is that I am now hoping he has read our natural heritage trust bill, and that is very promising because at least the opposition is starting to focus on some of the programs—the revegetation program, the Murray‐Darling, the coast and clean seas, and the national reserve. Thirdly, in relation to the trust fund, you are wrong.

—My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. You would be aware that regulations and complying legislation increased enormously during the 13 years of Labor administration. In fact, the income tax act approximately tripled in size during that time. Minister, I ask you: how is the new government going to deal with this difficult legacy of Labor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an enormous challenge. There is no doubt about that. One of the reasons Labor lost government was so many small businesses went broke trying to pay the compliance costs of Labor's tax laws. It is fascinating that, since it went into opposition, Labor has wanted to concentrate on the issue of taxation administration. It is a pity it did not do a bit more of it when it was in government. Not only did individual tax take rise from $29 billion—
—Because of economic growth.
—Order!

—to $62 billion in 1984‐85, but the tax act grew from 1,300 pages to 4,000 pages. I wonder how many honourable senators on the other side have tried to understand the tax act that they drafted. Senator Sherry sees himself as an expert on this subject. Do you remember section 82KTJ?

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Hill. We will stop the clock again and wait for silence. Senator Hill.
—It reads:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . a car is a predecessor of a second car if a third car is a predecessor of the second car and the first‐mentioned car is a predecessor of the third car (including a case where the first‐mentioned car is a predecessor of the third car by another application or applications of this paragraph).
This is the sort of nonsense that you expected small business people to interpret and to comply with.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —And no wonder they went broke trying to do so. Compliance with your fringe benefits tax is believed to cost Australian businesses $900,000 a day. That act is now 300 pages long.
—Did you vote for it?
—A study by the Australian Tax Research Foundation found that complying with company tax provisions was—
—Did you vote against it?
—just listen to this; it is important—22.9 per cent of company income tax.
—Are you on the division list voting for it? Come on. Did you vote for it, you bozo?

—You do not understand these things, do you? You do not now how hard it is for small business to survive, let alone employ more Australians. Do you realise that compliance costs of Australian taxation laws are believed to be 10 times greater than that in the United Kingdom? This is the example of your administrative failure in a critically important area that cost Australians dearly—it cost Australians jobs. If you had concentrated a bit more on that when you were in government, then we all would have been better off.

BREAK.PARA: What does the new government intend to do? As you would be well aware from the plans we have announced, our intention is to simplify the FBT rules on entertainment and car parking; to double the ceiling for FBT‐exempt minor benefits; to consider aligning the FBT year to the income tax year; to allow CGT rollover relief; to double the time that beneficiaries have to sell inherited homes CGT‐free; to exempt the sale of business used to fund retirement, and so I could go on. I am saying that the new government has a comprehensive program of reform to improve the mess that we have inherited in terms of Australia's taxation laws and to give small business, in particular, a fair go.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I appreciate the formidable list that you have just given, Senator Hill. I was wondering whether it would be possible to give further examples of how the government, as you said, intends to, overcome this formidable legacy of Labor's mismanagement.

—I could tell you about the small business deregulation task force. I could tell you about all the efforts that we are putting in place to give small business the chance to grow. The difference is that we on this side of the chamber—we who are now in government—have some empathy with small business. We understand the difficulties facing small business in the challenge of growing and employing. It was the crushing of small business by your policies—not only the tax administration, but your interest rate policies—that put so many Australians out of work. Fortunately for small business, there is now a change—
—Rubbish!
—Senator Schacht!

—You were the failed small business minister, Senator Schacht. You ask small business what they think of your record. They came strongly on board in the last election and they still have our support. (Time expired)
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—On 30 May Senator Wheelwright asked me a question in relation to stock exchange listings of Telstra. In order to help him fill in the long hours after 30 June when he will have to look for a real job for a change, I have some additional information which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard .
—Not granted! Let him read it out!
—Leave is not granted. You will have to read out your answer.
—It's left the chamber; I will do it another day.
—Do it now.
—He hasn't got it with him now.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Robert Ray asked me three questions in one in relation to the funding of parliamentary departments and committees. I have a response to those questions, which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard .

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The response read as follows—
SUGGESTED RESPONSE:

EMPHASIS.TAB: Question 1: Why has the agreement between the Department of Finance and the Senate regarding the funding of Senate Committees been rescinded by an officer of the Department of Finance rather than by the Minister?

The Department of Finance did not rescind any agreement relating to the funding of Senate Committees. After taking into account the very difficult Budget situation that the Government was facing, officials advised the Department of the Senate that the request for funds should be considered in the normal Budget process.
The President of the Senate has agreed to this, and the Minister for Finance agreed to fund certain undertakings of select committees relating to the current financial year.

Question 2: Why has the Minister for Finance requested a joint submission from the five parliamentary departments when the Coalition vigorously opposed amalgamation of parliamentary departments on the principle of immutable division of responsibilities?

The Minister for Finance requested a joint submission from the Presiding Officers in the interests of efficient public administration of the Parliament. The Government is trying to promote greater cooperation between the five parliamentary departments because it believes this will enhance operational efficiencies.
Question 3: Do the recommendations of the Department of Finance mean that there is no funding at all in the next financial year for the two latest select committees?

I repeat what I said yesterday that Government decisions on funding will in the normal course of events be announced in the Budget. On the funding new Senate Select Committees and Senate funding in general, there is an orderly process of addressing this in the development of the 1996‐97 budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a short statement in relation to an answer to the supplementary question given by Senator Herron during question time today. I think the third question asked in question time today was a question directed to Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, from Senator Bob Collins. After the primary question asked by Senator Collins was answered Senator Collins directed a supplementary question to Senator Herron. I believe that these are the words that Senator Herron used to begin his supplementary answer:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Why is Senator Collins so aggressive and abusive in his behaviour? Why does he bash his wife at night, Mr President? Why does he do these things, Mr President? I mean, its a pure example of his behaviour in this regard. I am happy to provide answers . . .
Because of interjections from the government side, I did not hear Senator Herron's words, but I consider that to be one of the most serious—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's taken you a long time to work up some indignation.
—I consider that to be one of the most serious abrogations of ministerial responsibility that we have heard in this chamber.
—About three months to work up some outrage!

—I will actually take the interjections from Senator Alston and say that the reason the opposition is responding now and has sought leave at the earliest opportunity after the conclusion of question time is because of constant interjections from government senators. It was not clear to senators on this side of the chamber what Senator Herron said. I do not believe that I am being unfair to Senator Herron by directly quoting what he has said.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to point out that when this government came to office the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, gave solemn assurances about ministerial conduct. In fact, he produced a document called A guide on key elements of ministerial responsibility. Section 5, relating to ministerial conduct, says:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Ministers must be honest in their public dealings and should not intentionally mislead the Parliament or the public. Any misconception caused inadvertently should be corrected at the earliest opportunity.

That is the Howard bible on ministerial responsibility. What Senator Herron has done is not only contrary to those ministerial guidelines but it is also a clear and very serious breach of the standing orders of this chamber. On behalf of the opposition, I ask for a full and complete withdrawal of those comments and an unconditional apology to Senator Collins.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President, before we proceed any further with this little exercise, could I ask you to direct Senator Faulkner to turn his mind to whether, from now on, he is going to refrain from calling out across the chamber `You fool' and various other obscenities which are clearly designed to lower the whole tone of this place, to bring the Senate into disrepute and to completely and utterly undermine any attempt to raise the standards. Is that what you are on about? You want business as usual on your side but you expect us to somehow set you a much better example.

—Perhaps I could use this opportunity to say that I have no doubt that the apology will be forthcoming. Knowing Senator Herron, I am sure he did not mean to say that. In response to what Senator Alston said, perhaps I could explain—
—Speak to the point of order.

—I am speaking to the point of order. Senator Alston took a point of order on double standards and I just wanted to point out to Senator Alston, and to you, Mr President, why the example he gave pales into insignificance compared with what is now going to appear in Hansard —and I have had it transcribed from a tape. People like Senator Kernot, and others who have known me for years, know why we are doing this. I know what Senator Herron meant to say. He meant to use that old expression `When are you going to stop beating your wife?'
—Yes, that is right.
—You are straying from the point of order. I think you have made your point.
—Then perhaps I could seek leave to simply make a statement.
—After we have dealt with the point of order. There is no point of order, although the general standards could rise on all sides, I must say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am sure that is what Senator Herron meant to say. I might say in passing that, even though it is a traditional expression, it is an expression which I always flinch at. I wish people would stop using it. Senator Herron and I have a few things in common. We both left home at the age of 15, we both washed our hands in solvol and we both come from Irish Catholic labour stock. I do not know whether you left home at 15 for the same reason as I did, Senator Herron. I hope you did not. That is why I am sensitive about this subject.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Herron had said that—and I really do wish people would stop using that expression—I would not have minded, but this is what he said and this is how it is going to appear in Hansard. The reason I am making this point—and, as I say, people like Senator Kernot know why I am making it—is that there will be people in the Northern Territory, I can assure you, Senator Herron, who, because you are Aboriginal affairs minister and because my wife is Aboriginal, will assume that you have been told something in your capacity that supports this statement. This is how it will read in Hansard unless it is corrected:

Why is Senator Collins so aggressive and abusive in his behaviour? . . . Why does he bash his wife at night, Mr President? Why does he do these things, Mr President? . . . it is a pure example of his behaviour in this regard.
I would appreciate a withdrawal and an apology.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lucky man! Senator Faulkner asked me the following question on 23 May 1996. I will not read the details of it but I indicate, since there was confusion once before when I simply referred to a date, that the question related to loopholes in the Secret Commissions Act and shelf companies being used by people involved in immigration rackets. I seek leave to incorporate an answer from the Attorney-General in Hansard .

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
ANSWER TO QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE
Senator Faulkner asked me the following questions without notice on 23 May 1996:

(1) Are there loopholes in the Secret Commissions Act 1905 which prevent the prosecution of individuals accepting secret commissions in the form of loans that are immediately forgiven for services rendered?
(2) Are shelf companies being used in this way by people involved in the immigration rackets?
ANSWER TO QUESTION (1)
The Attorney-General has provided me with the following answer:

PARA.TAB: No. Section 4 of the Secret Commissions Act 1905 provides it is an offence for any agent without the full knowledge of the principal, to directly or indirectly, accept or obtain any gift or consideration as an inducement or reward for any act done or not done.

The Act is of course governed by the limits of Commonwealth jurisdiction. `Agent' includes servants of the Crown and employees of corporations, but the Act only reaches corporations which are engaged in interstate or international trade and is rarely used in that sphere.
`Consideration' is defined to mean:

ANSWER.PARA: "valuable consideration of any kind, and particularly includes discounts, commission and rebates, bonuses, deductions and percentages and also employment. . . "

PARA.TAB: Additionally subsection 4(2) provides that a gift or consideration is deemed to be given as an inducement or reward if the receipt or any expectation thereof would be in any way likely to influence the agent to do or leave undone something contrary to his or her duty.

The secret commissions offence has a very broad reach and would certainly cover bogus loans such as those described by Senator Faulkner in his question. If it can be shown the offender used a shelf company and benefited from the transaction in that way it would come within the scope of the element of the offence which deals with obtaining consideration indirectly.

ANSWER.PARA: ANSWER TO QUESTION (2).

PARA.TAB: The Australian Federal Police advises it is not aware of any shelf companies being used in the way suggested by this question but would be interested in receiving any evidence that you may have concerning such issues."

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—During question time today Senator Bell raised a question with the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, which purported to quote me in a newspaper article. From memory, I think Senator Bell said that I supported a conditional ban on woodchip exports. The way that was said, it may be misinterpreted. Therefore, I have obtained the press cutting from Senator Bell. I think it is worthwhile reading into the Senate record precisely what I was reported to have said on that occasion. The article is from the Australian on 21 March 1995. Among other things, it indicates that I:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . Supported a ban on the export of woodchips from forests not subject to regional agreements under the National Forest Policy Statement by the year 2000.
Having read the full statement, I think it puts a substantially different spin on it from the question that was posed by Senator Bell to Senator Hill.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—At the end of question time today, Senator Alston sought leave to incorporate into Hansard an answer providing further information on a question he had previously been asked. By the time Senator Ray and I brought to your attention that leave was not to be granted, the information had been passed from Senator Alston to the attendant. By the time he got it back, we had moved on to another matter. Now that Senator Alston is no longer here, I want to make sure that the material is not incorporated into Hansard and that Senator Alston will have to come back at a later time and read it out.
—Leave was not granted so it will not be incorporated. It is quite clear.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to a question without notice asked by the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate (Senator Boswell) today, relating to the proposed partial privatisation of Telstra.

No self-respecting, public‐opinion polling company would put their name to this shonky poll. Let us firstly look at the sampling. What do we find? There were 860 participants on the farm-wide, on-line pilot project. That is no random sample. That is a very selective group of farmers.

Let us secondly look at the loaded questions. Question No. 1: do you think the telecommunications you get at present from Telstra could be improved? Yes, said 79.3 per cent. Question No. 2, which was connected, of course: so, do you think the partial privatisation of Telstra will improve telecommunications services? Yes, said only 41.62 per cent; no and unsure, said 58.25 per cent. This was not dwelled upon in the national farmers press release which went with it—even after that first loaded question. Question No. 3: do you think the use of $1 billion from the partial privatisation of Telstra is a good idea? What a surprise! Yes, said 73 per cent. What loaded, linked questions are these, when they start with `Do you think that the partial sale of Telstra—'.

I think that this calls into question—yet again—the independence of the National Farmers Federation. It does not take us long to remember that this is the group for which the now Liberal Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) was the executive director.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ian McLachlan was president, not executive director.
—This does not allow us to forget, of course, Mr Andrew Robb in his present role with the Liberal Party, and Rick Farley, who is no longer with them and playing a role.

—Madam Deputy President, on a point of order: Mr McLachlan has been maligned. He was never executive director of NFF; he was president of NFF. If you want to know a bit more about this at the same time, Senator Crane was deputy president. If she wants to criticise the NFF, and I am the first one to criticise them when I have to—
—Senator Panizza, you will direct your remarks through the chair.
—Then she ought to get her facts straight.
—There is no point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to correct the title to `the president' of the NFF. The point is that the same Mr Andrew Robb, who is now telling all of us to take notice of this survey, is the one who in the election cam paign pulled out of the bottom draw another little shonky survey. It was purported to involve 400 under‐35-year-old undecided voters. Guess what question No. 1 was—do you support or oppose a major increase of expenditure on the environment in Australia? That is a nice little general leading question. How many people are going to say no? Only seven per cent said no. How many said yes? It was 86 per cent. What a big surprise!

ANSWER.PARA: Second question: do you support or oppose—this is totally linked—the coalition's plans to use $1 billion for the Telstra fund? Yes, said 55 per cent; 40 per cent opposed. No other options were proposed, like, `Do you think the government has a responsibility to fund it from the core budget?' or `Do you think that there are other ways to fund the environment?' They were not asked at all.

Contrast this kind of shonky methodology with the work of Mr Hugh Mackay. These were not totally selective, quantitative measurements but it was longitudinal, qualitative work. It was taking the time to ask in detail what people think. As reported in the Weekend Australian of 8 and 9 June, this is what he found Australians think:

Although the Government seems unwilling to face it, the reality is that the electorate voted in a deliberate way in the March election. Voters supported the Coalition handsomely in the House of Representatives and, in votes cast for the Senate by the very same people on the very same day, they gave similarly handsome support to the non-Coalition parties.

So, how strongly is the community opposed to the privatisation of Telstra, and why? The answer is that opposition to the sale of Telstra is about as strong as the community's support for tougher gun laws.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is suitably impressed by the great weight of public opinion behind his initiatives on that question. Perhaps he will also come to respect the depth of support for the position of Labor plus the Democrats on Telstra. This is just another shonky NFF piece of propaganda, the mouthpiece of the Liberal Party. It should be rejected as just that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President—

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, it is a well established fact now that the Democrats are in coalition with the Labor Party. I ask Senator Kernot to pick one side of the chamber and then the alternative side.
—I am sure that Senator Woodley will defer to you, Senator Boswell.
—Not after that nastiness.
—Senator Woodley may be a minority in his own party, but he does have a voice of his own.
—Senator Boswell, if you have the call you should be addressing the motion before the chair.

—Madam Deputy President, this is a classic case: if you do not like the messenger, and if you do not like what 870 farmers have said in a clear, concise questionnaire, then you just rubbish the messenger. So today Senator Kernot, the Leader of the Australian Democrats, has just put the boot into a questionnaire because—
—It deserves to be rubbished.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it deserves to be rubbished, in your opinion, because it does not come up with the answers that you want. Some 870 farmers have answered very simple questions such as: do you think the telecommunications you get at present from Telstra should be improved? I could say that many millions of Australians would say that the support they get from Telstra is questionable. The answer is yes. What is more plain than that? About 70 per cent of the people believe that the service can be improved.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us take the last question: do you think that a partial sale of Telstra is a good idea? Some 66.40 per cent of farmers believe that they want Telstra to be partially privatised. Why do they want it? It is clear to them that they will benefit from the partial sale of Telstra. They will get $1 billion spent on the environment. They are aware of the desperate need to improve the environment as far as primary industry is concerned. They will be deprived of $300 million for revegetation.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Kernot cannot stand getting a bit of flack. She is off. She spent 1½ hours at lunch today, and that is the fourth time she has missed question time in the last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I am sorry, I cannot wait around for a personal explanation but I really object to the misrepresentation that has occurred in this chamber in the last couple of days over whether I am in question time or not. On Tuesday I was in Perth and today I was here.
—No‐one said you were not; I said you were half an hour late. Listen, Senator Kernot, when you—
—Senator Boswell, address your remarks through the chair, please.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, if Senator Kernot was prepared to put the boot in, so to speak, she could not question anyone then coming back and answering her. There are a couple more points I would like to make, and the first related to river care.

ANSWER.PARA: Rivers are full of saline. Another $30 million was going to improve the river systems of Australia. We need clean water. We need clean water for the animals and for the crops. Australian farmers are going to be deprived of that $30 million. The Murray-Darling system is falling to pieces. Anyone with the slightest idea of the need to improve the Murray-Darling system would be only too pleased to support the use of $100 million to improve the Murray-Darling system.

So you can understand why the farmers have overwhelmingly supported the partial sale of Telstra. They were very surprised that the support they thought they would get from the Democrats was not forthcoming. They believed that the Democrats were genuinely interested in the environment. Senator Kernot and her merry bunch of Democrats over there are on a hide into nothing on this one. They painted themselves into a corner. They cannot retreat. They want it to go away.

Every time this issue is raised, Senator Kernot's constituency scratches its head and says, `I voted for the Democrats to support the environment. Why are we being shunted off in other areas? Why can't Senator Kernot, who said she was committed to the environment, support the sale of Telstra so $1 billion can be spent on improving the environment of Australia?' Senator Kernot, you are sending out a double message that really has your constituency in doubt. I know that this embarrasses you. I know that every day you come here you squirm with embarrassment because you cannot defend your position. It is indefensible. (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how many senators would have seen the episode of Yes, Minister where Sir Humphrey Appleby showed Bernard how to design a questionnaire to get the desired result. That is exactly the kind of questionnaire we have before us. It is extremely shonky. It is not a random survey to start with, Senator Boswell. If you want to do a survey which is going to provide you with a result that can be trusted, the first rule is that it must be a random survey, not a survey of a particular group of farmers—the rich farmers who in fact have an ISDN capacity. They are the farmers who were surveyed in this case. I can assure you that the majority of farmers do not have that facility in their homes, but the ones the NFF surveyed did have on this occasion.

ANSWER.PARA: I really do not want to attack the NFF because we have given it a bit of a hiding on this issue. I hope Senator Bob Collins is listening because I have an account to settle with him later. It is a big debate about how many farmers peak bodies actually represent. The PGA in Western Australia has estimated, for example, that the Wool Council—and it has had this checked—represents about 40 per cent of wool growers. How many farmers does the NFF represent? That is a pretty fair question, if that is what you are going to put up in your argument.

Another issue which Senator Boswell raised was the fact that he took the last question as giving the strongest result. It certainly does. Again, it comes in a series of questions. Anybody knows that when you ask questions in that kind of order you predetermine that the final question will be the one that you really want to read. The second question, however, is very significant: do you think the partial privatisation of Telstra will improve telecommunication services? Only 41.62 per cent answered that question and, as Senator Kernot said, 58 per cent of respondents really did not know.

Let me tell you something else. We ran this questionnaire past the Democrats' party room. To question No. 1, `Do you think the telecommunications you get at present from Telstra could be improved?', not 70 per cent but 100 per cent of Democrats responded that telecommunications services could be improved. That is how skewed your questionnaire is.

Senator Boswell, I really believe that you should be looking after your rural constituency. It is dangerous for you to be used as a pawn by the Liberal Party to ask their questions so that they can give the dorothy dix answers that they want you and others to believe. The problem for the National Party is that the Liberal Party is giving them a hiding. You should not be part of that.

We would prefer to support you in many of the initiatives you would take in the bush if only the Liberal Party would let you. But we know that there is almost a conspiracy going on whereby almost every decision that this coalition government has made has put it to your rural base. It is about time you stood up for your constituency and stopped allowing the Liberal Party to use you as part of the plot to bash the bush.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is common practice when you do not like the results of a survey to attack its methodology. I have another survey result for Senator Kernot. I see she is leaving.
—I have to go.
—I was going to remind you of the survey in the Sydney Morning Herald . Do you remember that one?
—Yes.
—It was an AGB McNair survey—very credible—that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald of 4 June. It showed that a majority of Australians now favour the sale of Telstra.
—Two per cent extra.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, you have come back. The survey conducted over 2,000 interviews and showed that a majority of Australians now favour the sale of Telstra. Support has gone up 10 per cent since the election. That is not surprising. This matter has the same history as the sale of any public asset.

ANSWER.PARA: When people are unfamiliar with an issue and are asked whether they support it, they give a very cautious response. Generally, they say no. That changes the more they become familiar with the benefits that can flow from the privatisation of the asset. In this instance, the benefits include having a telecommunications company that is genuinely internationally competitive and consumers paying lower prices for calls—as happened with the privatisation of British Telecom. The more that people focus on the public benefits that flow from resources being freed up by the sale of the asset, the more in favour they are of the sale. That is exactly what is happening with this matter.

The more the community starts to focus on the benefits that can flow from the sale—the benefits to Telstra and its services; the benefit of the repayment of public debt which will take pressure off interest rates, help small businesses to prosper and to employ more Australians; and the benefit of a $1 million investment in our natural capital—the more it will support the sale. The graph is up; already a majority of Australians are now in favour.

As I said in question time, I do not understand why the Australian Democrats, the Greens and the Labor Party will not listen to the people on this issue. Senator Kernot had a number of arguments against the sale. She started off by saying that the Democrats were opposed to it because it would result in higher charges, and she used British Telecom as an example. That argument was demonstrated to be false; she was wrong. She then said the sale would harm rural people. Now rural people have said that they are in favour of the sale, so she has lost that argument as well. The pattern has continued and she is left with no other basis for her argument than ideology, which is where she started.

The Greens and the Democrats have always been opposed to any sale of a public asset no matter what the case for the sale might be. Such are the ideological blinkers in which they operate and always have. At least they are more honest in that regard than the ALP. They say that they are opposed but they were prepared to sell Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank, and we all know that had they been re‐elected they would have sold Telstra in a flash. Their argument is simply one of political convenience because they want to take an opposite position from the new government.

With the Greens and the Democrats it is pure ideology. But with their ideological blinkers on, the losers are the economy—therefore all of us—and our natural heritage. Never before has there been a chance to invest so much capital in our environment. Never before has the need for that investment been as great.

It is not too late, Senator Margetts—if you are going to contribute to this debate—for you to recognise that you have a chance to come on board and be part of this exciting project: to put all this money into revegetation, into improving our coasts, our seas and our river systems, and into an extended conservation reserve system, things which your supporters would wholeheartedly applaud. You could be part of this exciting project if only you could break free of those ideological blinkers that are not allowing you to think laterally on this matter. I invite the Greens and the Democrats to give this matter further consideration before it is too late. (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There are obviously a few issues I would like to add to today's debate. First of all, what we seem to have presented to us today is an implication that Commonwealth taxpayers—that is, everybody in Australia who pays tax—should be left to pay for poor state land use and planning decisions. To give an example, in Western Australia there is currently a massive increase in requests by primary producers for land clearance. We are looking at something like 22,000 hectares.

ANSWER.PARA: If we do not see a change in the decisions made to reduce greenhouse sinks, to decrease the quality of water and to add to the eutrophication of our river systems and we do not ever get to the point of making the changes that will work on the community changing their land use patterns, there are only so many ways we can bleed taxpayers to pay for those mistakes. We cannot continue to assume that we can come in here and find some magic pudding that will fix up the mistakes of the states without ever looking at how we have made those mistakes in the first place and how we can turn around the situation and stop this from happening.

There have been a lot of very strange statements about the Greens' position in relation to Telstra, but one of the issues that has not come out very clearly is that there are huge problems in the Telstra bill in relation to the environment. Basically, the greater level of privatisation there is in telecommunications, the less control there is of governments or any other bodies in relation to the environmental standards of the telecommunications system, whether it be in provision of telephones or other telecommunications infrastructure.

If we are currently getting shocking reports from communities who are racking their brains in fighting decisions on towers and cables because their habitat is being destroyed in order to put up cables and towers, people's amenities, and if there are local concerns about people's proximity to technology which may cause health problems because of rays and so on, we as a Senate should know how difficult it would ever be to address those problems once we have gone down the road of closing off any direct parliamentary input into the standards by which telecommunications carriers operate.

Currently there are problems—and you cannot put the argument that there are problems now so how would it be any worse if we privatised Telstra. To begin with, we have an opportunity to try to redress the environmental problems that exist in the current telecommunications operation and no effort has been made to do that. It will not happen if we go ahead with privatising Telstra even a little on the assumption that we can pull back and impose state and federal laws on those carriers which do not exist now.

Anyone who thinks that will be possible has not looked at the history of trying to reimpose rules and regulations on a privatised firm once they have got into contracts and once there is a reasonable expectation from the people lining up to buy it—in this case, a telecommunications network—that they will be subject to the same kinds of rules and regulations or lack thereof that exist now. If that is not clearly delineated before any process takes place, what on earth do you think will happen further to the Australian environment?

We have heard already from community groups right around Australia that they are concerned not only about fights for two lines of cables but about multitudinal fights for multitudinal lines that will occur if we do not address these kinds of problems before we take any other step. Whatever the Greens believe about the step of privatisation, you have no credibility talking about our credibility on the environment till you even acknowledge that those problems exist even within the Telstra legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate today relates to an answer to a question about a survey by the National Farmers Federation. I remind the Senate of that because we may have stepped off the mark a little. Some of the points that Senator Margetts raised are absolutely vital to this debate, however. They of course refer to what Telstra's environmental credentials are and whether they will improve or go backwards under a partial privatisation.

ANSWER.PARA: My strong belief—Senator Margetts may have this belief as well, if she is anything like me and probably many other members and senators around this building—is that, in relation to trying to have the people's voice heard through the parliamentary process this year and in past years on issues such as Telstra towers and other actions by Telstra relating to environmental matters, the situation could not get any worse. Trying to control Telstra through these parliamentary processes is a failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the government; you can change that.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —We are seeking to change it, Senator Margetts, by seeing that Telstra becomes more efficient and more responsive to the community and shareholders through partial privatisation. One of the problems we have with Telstra that seem to have alluded a number of commentators—I say to the lady from the AAP sitting in the press gallery that I would really love someone to write a story about this—is that Telstra is a large and inefficient organisation owned by the public sector. On all of the international criteria for measuring the performance and efficiency of Telstra as an organisation, economically and environmentally it does not come up to the mark.

ANSWER.PARA: I suggest we look at whether the environment will benefit from the sale of Telstra. Ignoring all the benefits from the Natural Heritage Trust, which the Greens have said they support but want to fund by either higher taxes or more debt—we want to fund it by equity already there—we should look at Telstra as an operation. It employs too many to provide the service it does. By international comparisons, it occupies far too much office space for the amount of service it provides and it provides many of the services to people more expensively than required, so it creates economic and environmental waste.

One of the great benefits of the partial privatisation of Telstra—and this has quite clearly become apparent to the farmers who were surveyed in the National Farmers Federation survey—is that consumers of Telstra's services will get economic benefits. There will be cheaper phone calls and better services for rural customers, which is clearly recognised by these farmers.

It is fair to say that, yes, it was a narrow based survey, but it is a very important message to the Australian Democrats and the Greens. They are saying that they are the farmers' friends and they want to keep Telstra in public ownership. What they are saying is, `Fund the environment package by putting taxes up or increasing borrowing'—therefore, putting up interest rates.

The farmers know that does not work. They have had 13 years of that response. They have had the Democrats' approach of paying for environmental rehabilitation by putting up taxes and putting up interest rates, but the farmers have said that they do not like that. They like the idea of having a more efficient Telstra. They like the idea of having lower phone calls. They like the idea of having better services. They love the idea of spending hundreds of millions of dollars on revegetation initiatives, river care initiatives and fixing up salinity in places like the Murray-Darling.

So it is a win, win, win for the farmers and it is a lose, lose, lose for the Democrats. They have gone way out in front of this debate. They have not listened to the people. These are the Democrats who are meant to go out and run polls and have participatory democracy. When every single poll comes out and says, `We want Telstra sold partially. We want $1.15 billion for the environment,' the Democrats say, `No. That is no good.' It does not matter whether Gary Morgan does the poll or Mr Saulwick does the poll or the National Farmers Federation does the poll. Unless Senator Kernot does the poll, it is not good enough. They would rather ignore it.

I do ask senators to look at the intrinsic environmental benefits of having an efficient telecommunications company that is not wasting money on office space it does not need and that is not burning up energy and power and creating greenhouse gases. Look at the benefits of its being responsive both to its shareholders and to the Australian public with regard to their very genuine concerns about things such as the placement of towers.

If you fly across the Nullarbor, Telstra dug a great gash through the middle of Australia when it put its optic fibre cable down. The consumers were very concerned about that. It was right past your back paddock, Senator Panizza. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the documents required under the motion which was passed this morning for questions in response to the supply bills and to make a brief statement.
—Senator Short, you do not need leave to table the documents. Although you are entitled to do that, you do need leave to make a statement.
—Before granting leave, could I ask Senator Short this: does the statement you are planning to make relate to the documents? Is that what you are suggesting to the Senate?
—Yes. I have just a few comments in relation to the documents I am tabling.
—Yes.

—I table the documents required under the notion of motion which was passed this morning and, in doing so, make a brief statement. I advise the Senate that I consider that the documents provide answers to all of the questions which were asked by Senators Chamarette and Margetts. However, some of the information is not as comprehensive as I would have liked, and that is due to the quite unreasonable time constraints that were placed on us and on departments to provide the material requested. It is clear that some departments were unable to respond in full detail to the questions within the time frame available. Nevertheless, I have provided as much information that is as comprehensive as possible on the basis of the time available.

SPEECH.PARA: You will see, Madam Deputy President, that the information is substantial—it totals more than 65 pages. Much of the information itself required collation by individual departments of details which were not otherwise available in that form, so it has been a very resource intensive exercise to get these answers together. I hope that the Senate, in particular Senators Chamarette and Margetts, appreciate that it has been very resource intensive and, therefore, a very costly exercise.

The Department of Finance was then involved in collating the information from across departments, as I explained to Senators Margetts and Chamarette on numerous other occasions, and that is a very difficult coordinating task in itself. Not only has that been a very difficult task but it has been a substantial task. It has involved officials working right through the night to prepare the information for today. In the light of this, I hope that Senator Margetts is prepared to concede that her request has been unreasonable, given the detail and substance of the answers provided.

I do not know whether you heard this, Senator Margetts, but to get this information to you today the officers of departments were required to work right through the night to do so. I would say that, given the time constraints, there may be some lack of full satisfaction with the detail provided by particular departments. It is, of course, open to senators to ask for additional or clarifying information. Unfortunately, given the constraints imposed, this may be necessary in this instance.

I conclude by putting on the record that in matters such as this the government wants to cooperate wherever it is proper and reasonable to do so in providing documents in a timely fashion. Such an approach is consistent with the government's very strong commitment to open and accountable government. That said, however, I think it is far better to allow sufficient time for information to be gathered so that what is provided to this place is both as comprehensive and as clear as possible to the provider and to those to whom it is being provided—in this case the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am appalled that the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short) should get up and say that my request, or the request of Senator Chamarette and me, was unreasonable. It was clearly stated from the Hansard that the offer was made and reinforced several times by the government. It was not an unreasonable request from the Greens; it was an assurance from the government. So what they are saying is that their assurance was unreasonable—in which case, their assurance was misleading to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: They can bash themselves on this issue all they like, but that is the reality. I am absolutely flabbergasted that Senator Short is suggesting we should apologise for accepting their offer. Does this mean we should apologise for ever believing an offer that is made to us in the future? How disgraceful! Is that what you are saying—that whatever you suggest in the future in relation to such offers we should automatically consider is unreasonable and unobtainable and that, therefore, it is unreasonable and unfair of us to expect you to meet your offer?

The apology should be coming from the government. You should be giving some explanation as to how the situation that the departments do not know what the ministers are deciding is being resolved. Why is it that it is taking your department so long to work out what the ministerial decisions are? A lot of the time I expect it is because they do not know. They had to find out what it was that was being said in their departments.

We have had statements from ministers that there are no cuts; there are no staff losses. But we are hearing from departments that they are all leaving with their redundancy packages because they have been asked to put their hands up to go. If that is what is happening, if when direct questions are being answered by, `There is nothing happening in this department,' it is not surprising that the departments are taking a long time to come up with the answer to the question of what is happening in their departments. A lot of them do not know yet. A lot of them have not been told by their own ministers what is happening. This is disgraceful! The apology should not be coming from this side; the apology should be coming from the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On the same theme as Senator Margetts, I can recall the debate on supply. It was almost three weeks ago. In fact, it will be three weeks ago tomorrow.
—You have a massive memory.

—It was a debate in which we cooperated, I would remind you, Senator Panizza. A request for information came from the Greens. I recall Senator Hill dashing in here to take over the debate from Senator Gibson. Senator Hill laid down the time frame on behalf of the government. It was not Senator Margetts who said, `We demand this information within two weeks.' It was Senator Hill who said, `We will get the information for you within a reasonable period of time.' I do not recall the exact words he used.
—He said `best endeavour'.

—Well, he should be very careful about how he uses those words. He certainly gave this chamber the impression that this material would be forthcoming. I do not agree with Senator Short that the Greens' request was unreasonable or that they did not give sufficient time for information to be provided.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not agree with Senator Short. It was Senator Hill who came into this chamber and made the offer to go away and have the material obtained. If the government could not obtain that material in the time period that they specified, there should have been some sort of explanation to the chamber. They should not come in here and berate Senator Margetts about the time frame that was set down.

It has been almost three weeks since that request. We are yet to have a look at the material that Senator Short has tabled here today. I suspect it is a little like the material we obtained in respect to the return to order matter that was the subject of a request some four or five weeks ago.

I think it is deeply regrettable that Senator Short should provide the information in the way that he did on behalf of the government and make totally incorrect assertions about Senator Margetts and lay some sort of blame on her and the Greens about there being insufficient time and it being an unreasonable approach. It was not. It was a commitment given by the government. It was a commitment that should have been met.

BREAK.PARA: The material provided today should not have been provided with the sort of extravagant and over‐the‐top language that we witnessed from Senator Short—not just in his brief comments, but also in question time. Unfortunately, we are becoming all too used to that sort of extravagance from Senator Short and other members of the government.
