DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods, Sen Bob

TALKER.NAME: Senator WOODS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the visit of the defence subcommittee to Exercise Kangaroo 95. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT ON THE VISIT OF THE DEFENCE SUB-COMMITTEE OF THE JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE TO EXERCISE KANGAROO 95

SPEECH.PARA: At the completion of each Kangaroo series exercise Defence undertakes a comprehensive review and assessment of all aspects of the exercise. The final Kangaroo 95 (K95) Post Exercise Report was considered during April 1996 and resulted in over two hundred recommendations being referred to the Services for comment and action.
The Report of the Defence Sub‐Committee's visit to K95 in August 1995 included a number of recommendations and remarks. The government response is as follows:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 1 (page 2)
The Committee considers that an overall briefing of this nature should be provided to the Committee at the start of any future visits to military exercises.

SPEECH.PARA: It is agreed that it is preferable to provide an overall briefing at the beginning of an exercise visit. For this particular exercise, the Committee requested to visit the Amphibious Task Group in Weipa. Due to air transport options and exercise activity, the visit to the Task Group was scheduled prior to commencing the formal itinerary in Darwin where the Committee was provided with an overall briefing on K95.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 2 (page 3)
The Committee was concerned about this lack of air mobility for the Blue Force in this Exercise scenario especially given the recent grounding of the Nomad aircraft.

SPEECH.PARA: The K95 Post Exercise Report reflects the fact that battalion air mobile operations were not sufficiently practised due to insufficient numbers of Black Hawks. Nevertheless, K95 incorporated some 19 complex tasks associated with exercising elements of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) in the conduct of joint operations. Of those 19, all but three were completely or substantially achieved. The exceptions were a Battalion air mobile operation, a Brigade cordon and search, and a Company night parachute operation.
The recent grounding of the Nomad aircraft did not impact on K95 (See also response to Final Remarks).

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 3 (page 4)
The Committee recommends that an Australian Federal Police presence be established on Thursday Island.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of establishing an AFP presence on Thursday Island has been under consideration for some time, but has previously been deferred due to the costs and competing priorities. However, as part of the recent review and restructuring of the AFP, it is proposed to outpost an officer to Thursday Island between May and October 1996 to determine the need for a permanent AFP presence in the region.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 4 (page 6)
The Committee recommends that the effectiveness of present arrangements be investigated to determine whether additional ARA personnel should be recruited to support the 51 FNQR Q Stores.

SPEECH.PARA: A review conducted in September 1995 by Army identified the need for an increase of ARA posi tions at 51 Far North Queensland Regiment (51 FNQR). Army has provided three positions by reallocation from NORFORCE and two of these are to be Quartermaster positions. Further reallocations or additional manpower will not proceed until the completion of the current review into Army and its structure, which includes a review of the employment of Regional Force Surveillance Units attached to NORFORCE, the Pilbara Regiment and 51 FNQR.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 5 (page 8)

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is concerned that the operational capability of the RAN, both at a military level and in other areas such as cyclone and natural disaster relief work, may be undermined by the paying off of HMAS Tobruk . As a result, the Committee is more inclined to the view that HMAS Tobruk should be retained.

In 1993, the then government approved the acquisition of two ex‐United States Navy Newport Class ships to replace HMAS Tobruk and the ageing HMAS Jervis Bay. The two new vessels, HMA Ships Manoora and Kanimbla, when modified will have greater capabilities than the ships they are replacing.

Within the existing Navy manpower ceiling, it was necessary to use the personnel numbers from Jervis Bay and Tobruk as offsets for the crew of the two new ships. Although Jervis Bay paid off in 1994, Tobruk will remain in service until the first amphibious ships enters RAN service, in order to maintain the ADF's amphibious capability. As with other RAN units, the new ships will be available for natural disaster relief.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 6 (page 8)
In future, the Committee recommends that an overall briefing take place before an inspection of the Forces involved.

SPEECH.PARA: See response to Recommendation 1.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 7 (page 9)

The Committee considers this command and control structure to be particularly unwieldy. Its inadequacies were demonstrated by the inability of the Blue Force to coordinate reaction to Exercise events in the Torres Strait. This points to the advantage of a single command and control structure incorporating one Joint Commander in the area of operations.

SPEECH.PARA: The K95 Post Exercise Report makes the same point repeatedly regarding the need for improvements in command and control structure. The revised ADF command arrangements announced by the Chief of the Defence Force in January 1996 respond directly to these deficiencies. In particular, the appointment of the Commander Australian Theatre to conduct campaign and operational level planning will alleviate the command and control difficulties noted by the Committee.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Final Remarks (page 13)
In particular, the Committee's visit to K95 raised the following significant issues:
. the significant impact that a well armed and organised aggressor could inflict in Northern Australia

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee observations are accurate but it should be stated that the likelihood of such an occurrence is remote. Any comments of this nature must be viewed in the context of Australia's geo‐strategic environment and the government's Defence policy. This government is committed to maintaining and enhancing Australia's security through a policy of defence self‐reliance, expanding security cooperation with regional countries and strengthening our alliances. Exercises such as K95 are used to test ADF capabilities relevant to our current strategic circumstances.

PARA.EMPHASIS: . the lack of air mobility in the Army especially given the recent grounding of the Nomad aircraft and problems with the Black Hawk helicopters

SPEECH.PARA: The problems associated with Black Hawk serviceability are well known. Defence has put in place a recovery plan to increase the availability of Black Hawk helicopters and there has already been significant improvement. The availability of aircrafts is expected to further improve in the latter half of this year.

Following the then government's decision to withdraw the Nomad from service with the ADF, interim arrangements were made to lease commercial aircraft. A longer term solution is being examined as part of Defence's ongoing force structure considerations.
. the future of HMAS Cairns as the only Naval Base in Far North Queensland, particularly when the Fremantle class patrol boats are replaced
HMAS Cairns will continue to function as an operating base for the new Offshore Patrol Combatant and minor fleet units following the withdrawal of the Fremantle Class Patrol Boats from service.

PARA.EMPHASIS: . the relative strength of Regular and Reserve personnel in 51 FNQR, the regulation of use and the maintenance of equipment in 51 FNQR, and the role played by members of 51 FNQR on behalf of state and Federal agencies

SPEECH.PARA: The relative strength of Regular and Reserve personnel in 51 Far North Queensland Regiment is Regulars 37 (7.5%) and Reserves 460 (92.5%). See also response to Recommendation 4.
The Regiment uses a wide range of equipment which is deployed over a vast area.

This does create difficulties but has not unduly hampered the effectiveness of the Regiment. Presently, there is limitation on the ability to leave equipment in remote patrol locations due to the lack of suitable secure facilities and this matter is being addressed.

The authorised role of 51 FNQR includes the requirement to develop a close working relationship with communities and local, state and federal authorities in its area of responsibility. On occasions, state and federal law enforcement agencies have requested support from 51 FNQR. This has been provided in accordance with approved procedures for the provision of Defence support to civil authorities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: . the personnel problems of the ADF including problems caused by repeated separation within Service families

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the personnel problems of the ADF, a recent Review of Personnel Policy Strategy, entitled `Serving Australia', has comprehensively addressed strategic issues relating to the recruitment, employment and financial conditions of service, family support as well as education and training for members of the ADF. The Report proposes a personnel policy strategy which ensures that people are accorded due weight in the broader framework of Defence business and activities. The Report also reaffirms that family support is an individual and ADF shared responsibility.

In the preparation of this Review, there was extensive consultation with Service members and other agencies and businesses, in Australia and overseas, as well as an examination of social, economic, industrial and organisational trends which would impact upon the ADF.
The aim of the proposed personnel policy strategy is to ensure that the ADF recruits and retains highly professional people from all sectors of the community.

The government acknowledges that military service places special demands on members. Inevitably these demands affect their families who are confronted with a range of difficulties not generally encountered in the civilian community. The positive contribution that families make to the morale, performance and retention of its personnel is acknowledged. Consequently, the government will ensure that ADF members and their families are not disadvantaged in comparison with the general community.

PARA.EMPHASIS: . problems caused by staff ceiling in each of the Services

SPEECH.PARA: The government is firmly committed to improving the `teeth to tail' ratio in the Defence organisation and bolstering the resources available to operational elements of the ADF.

The Department of Defence and the government regularly monitor and review the personnel numbers of the ADF within the context of the overall Defence budget. However, many of the present difficulties relate to shortfalls in employment categories. Initiatives in recent years have been aimed at redirecting military staff to higher priority tasks, thereby enhancing the capabilities of the ADF. This has included initiatives such as the Commercial Support Program, Defence Regional Support Review and Defence Logistics Redevelopment Project. A major review of the Army and its structure is currently under way and will be submitted to the government shortly for consideration.
. the wisdom of the paying off of HMAS Tobruk given the impact of this decision on the RAN's operational capability and the gap its paying off will create
See response to Recommendation 5.

PARA.EMPHASIS: . the adequacy of the present limit to existing Reserve paid training days

SPEECH.PARA: The Reserve forces have adequate training days to meet objectives, although there are a number of administrative limits imposed for Reserve service. Under current policy, Reservists can serve for no more than 100 days per year. To maximise the training benefit of Reserve training days, Reservists may only complete 70 days training without permission of a formation commander. However, these administrative limits do not compromise the effectiveness of the Reserve force where the average attendance is approximately 40 days of service per year.

The government has directed that a broad ranging review be undertaken of Reserve service, training, roles, capabilities and preparedness. This review is likely to lead to significant changes to the nature of Reserve service and its contribution to the overall ADF capability.

PARA.EMPHASIS: . the importance of the early acquisition of Airborne Early Warning and Patrol Aircraft (AEW&C).

SPEECH.PARA: The government has stated that an Airborne Early Warning and Control (AEW&C) capability is a highly desirable longer term asset for Australia's defence. Project definition studies are being conducted with the aim of identifying an affordable option which meets Australia's needs.

PARA.EMPHASIS: . the necessity of a single command and control structure incorporating one Joint Commander in the area of operations

SPEECH.PARA: See response to Recommendation 7.

PARA.EMPHASIS: . the integration of women into the ADF and the demonstrable recognition of the positive role they played in the Exercise

SPEECH.PARA: Defence has made considerable progress in regard to the integration of women in the ADF. All positions, other than some combat positions, are now open to women.
At the completion of Exercise Kangaroo 95, the following signal was sent by the Chief of the Defence Force to all who had participated in the Exercise:

`This signifies the end of a long and complex activity designed to exercise and test the ADF in its principal role—the defence of Australia. I wish all participants to know that the lessons learned will be carefully derived and thoughtfully applied. The individual and collective contributions of you all—often in stressful and arduous conditions—have been marked by a level of professionalism and dedication which is well appreciated. Well done.'
The ADF acknowledges the positive role all members played in Exercise Kangaroo 95. The women involved were excellent role models for other women in the ADF.

PARA.EMPHASIS: . the participation of observers from other countries as a bilateral confidence building measure and as a means of improving communication between countries of the region

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's observations are supported. Improving our regional security dialogue at both a bilateral and regional level is one of the key aspects of the government's defence policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to speak at length to this document but one response to a recommendation in the report on the visit of the defence subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade jumped off the page—recommendation 1 on page 2. This recommendation relates to us going first of all to North Queensland and not being given any briefing on the exercise until we arrived in Darwin. The recommendation states:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee considers that an overall briefing of this nature should be provided to the Committee at the start of any future visits to military exercises.

SPEECH.PARA: The response states:

It is agreed that it is preferable to provide an overall briefing at the beginning of an exercise visit. For this particular exercise, the Committee requested to visit the Amphibious Task Group in Weipa. Due to air transport options and exercise activity, the visit to the Task Group was scheduled prior to commencing the formal itinerary in Darwin where the Committee was provided with an overall briefing on K95.

I want to know how it is that Defence is suggesting what the committee should hear and when. We did not go to Weipa first. We were in Cairns. I am wondering why it is that Defence is telling the committee when it is allowed to hear a briefing and why it was not possible for Defence to provide information about the exercise when the committee first met.

It is as though the committee had been very naughty because it went to a different side of the country before Defence was prepared to speak to it about the exercise. It possibly homes in on the fact that Defence does tend to be a law unto itself. Recommendation 6 on page 8 states:
In future, the Committee recommends that an overall briefing take place before an inspection of the Forces involved.
The response states:
See response to Recommendation 1.

It is not good enough. I can actually think of better things to do with my non-sitting times than to go around Australia and watch war games. However, I did it because I thought it was for me, as a parliamentarian and representing the Green electorate, to understand what these issues were. I do not go there just to see military facilities. I go there to understand the operations of the activities. Therefore, I stress that, if the response from Defence is, `We'll give you a briefing when it suits us,' it is not good enough. In future, I think that kind of attitude should change.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Report No. 30 of 1995‐96—Performance Audit—Implementation of Competition in Case Management—Employment Services Regulatory Authority—Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This Auditor's report could not have come at a worse time for the government in so far as it indicates to one and all just how important ESRA is—ESRA being the Employment Services Regulatory Authority. ESRA was established some two years ago as part of the Working Nation package. The Working Nation package has seen expenditure in this year of some $2.3 billion and over the life of the program considerably more—some $9 billion dollars in total.

What we have seen through the Working Nation package is quite substantial real improvements in the levels of job opportunities, particularly for those who are long-term unemployed. In the last few years the figures that I have at my disposal—up to August 1995—show that long-term unemployment fell by some 23.2 per cent or 231,000.

Of course, any figure like that is unacceptable, but the fact that the level of long-term unemployment fell by that figure suggests to me that substantial achievements have been made. Working Nation programs were aimed at providing access to job placements through the job compact, at providing access to labour market places for those who fall outside the job compact and at providing individual assessments and early assistance to reduce the risk of long-term unemployment.

The whole model of case management, which stands at the core of the operations of the Employment Services Regulatory Authority, is an innovative approach which we have not seen in many places throughout the world. It provided an opportunity for individual attention to be paid to people in our society who have become long-term unemployed.

In my judgment, it also allows an opportunity for state to become directly involved in fulfilling its responsibilities to ensure that there is the lowest possible level of unemployment in the country as a whole. One of the most important roles that the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs could have would be to prevent and to reduce the levels of long-term unemployment in our society.

ESRA was one part of a package of measures that went to Nettforce, that went to government programs, that went to a whole range of issues to do with the training agenda. These measures involved the way in which the Labor government approached matters in terms of TAFE training, schools, universities and other educational institutions.

It did stand very much as an important part of that overall package. The Auditor-General has pointed to the fact that ESRA has worked very well. The report indicates at page 8 that ESRA was able to be measured clearly against quite objective criteria and, when measured against those criteria, performed extremely well. Since the establishment of ESRA in July 1994, there have been some 3,257 case managers set in place. In that period, those case managers have been able to assist some 691,000 clients and provide quite substantial levels of assistance to the long-term unemployed in this country.

When the program was established, it was set down that there should be quite specific targets to see that the number of long-term unemployed were dealt with individually and were provided with individual attention, rather than be dealt with by an inhuman and at times distant bureaucracy. Case management now accounts for some 37 per cent of persons who are eligible for assistance. That is a significant movement in such a short period of time.

The Auditor-General pointed out that ESRA was able to fulfil the substantive objectives set down for it. The report states clearly at page 5 that ESRA was able to demonstrate that it was following a corporate plan, which set out its values, directions and strategies for the next three years; that it was able to fulfil an appropriate performance level and was able to provide a proper process of review and accountability; that it was able to establish effective means of fraud control and fraud risk assessments; and that it was able to put in place a management strategy that ensured money was well spent. It seems to me that that is an appropriate measure by which one can assess whether or not agencies such as this are performing well. That is what the Auditor-General essentially has indicated.

This report could not come at a worse time for the government because day after day we read of this government's determination to slash labour market programs, to undermine the rights of workers in this country, to turn the clock back to a period in our history when workers could not rely upon effective, individual and appropriate levels of assistance from the government and to leave people to their own devices. They are precisely the sorts of policies that this government has been pursuing. It has been saying that this is an indulgence, that labour market programs of this type are inappropriate and that we are spending too much money on assisting the long-term unemployed in this country. In my judgment, the government has a very inhuman approach to the questions of employment and unemployment.

What have we seen since this government has come to office? We have seen an attempt to denigrate the efforts of the former government. What they cannot hide is the fact that there have been such prolonged periods of employment growth which have led to substantial reductions in the numbers of long-term unemployed at a time when there have been increasing levels of participation and the rights of people to participate in the work force have been exercised, a right being recognised by increasing numbers of Australians. It is appropriate that they should recognise that right.

What do we see from this government? We see constant attacks upon the unemployed, attacks upon labour market programs and constant speculation about the levels of cuts to the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. There has been the suggestion that some 22 per cent of the budget targeted cuts should come from this department and that, in particular, some $400 million should come from labour market programs.

In those circumstances, the Auditor-General's report is quite timely. It highlights that it is not appropriate to attack bodies such as this that are doing a good job, that are ensuring that people's rights to participate in our society are implemented and not undermined by the government itself. In my judgment such discussion and speculation about removing support for such important agencies as this is inappropriate .

In terms of the government's overall program, one can only be led to the conclusion that the effects on economic growth of the proposed cuts of some $8 billion will be a reduction in economic growth. There will be an increase in the levels of unemployment. There will a greater need for agencies such as this. This is the great irony. The government is undermining any objectives it might have about improving the levels of employment in this country. In my judgment it is undermining the democratic nature of this country. One of the most fundamental democratic rights has to be the right to participate. The right to participate at work has to be central to that.

It seems to me that this is a very timely report. I welcome it. It needs to be carefully considered by the parliament. I look forward to being proved wrong in the coming budget session. I trust that the government will not proceed with its inhuman, callous disregard for the rights of Australia's long-term unemployed and that it will sustain programs such as this, which have obviously been performing very well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senator MICHAEL BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —I am intrigued by Senator Carr's handling of this report. I agree with him when he says that he wants this report carefully considered by this parliament, but I would suggest that Senator Carr carefully read the report now because his selective extracts from the audit report are incredible. In the first place, what he reported as commendation by the Auditor on page 8 is in fact a response from the departments themselves, praising themselves for their own activities—totally misleading of the Senate. That was an absolutely incredible performance, but a typical one by Senator Carr.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what this audit report really did say. It gives a very different impression indeed from the one just given to the Senate by Senator Carr. For example, when Senator Carr said that the audit found that they had made substantial progress in establishing, within the one-year time frame, an appropriate administrative framework, he failed then to say the next bit where the Auditor-General's report says:
As the majority of the CCMs had been operating for a short time, it was not possible to establish conclusively whether the administrative framework was operating effectively in practice.

How remarkable it was that Senator Carr could not read that sentence. Incredible, is it not? As I said, I hope the Senate does take a great deal of notice of this report. It is a very sensible and balanced report, unlike the submission just made to the Senate by Senator Carr. He probably assumes that no-one reads these reports and he can get away with this kind of nonsense. The Auditor-General goes on to say:

On the strategic front, the ANAO highlighted some concerns surrounding the competitive framework, for example ESRA's role in regulation and monitoring the case management system. These concerns were raised by the Department, ESRA and other relevant stakeholders.

But not according to Senator Carr. Everything in the garden is lovely, according to Senator Carr. I am not saying that this audit report proves the thing to be a disaster—not at all. All I am trying to do is bring some balance into the discussion in the chamber of this audit report. In particular, I thought I should deal with some quite serious concerns that the Auditor-General found. He said, for example:
. . . that there were a number of issues central to the framework which were still to be resolved some two years after the then Government's decision to implement competition in case management.

Two years after the event, issues central to the framework were still to be resolved. You would not have known that by listening to Senator Carr. It is just unbelievable that he would dare to come into this place and misrepresent an Auditor's report, as he has done today. It is absolutely disgraceful but, I might say, not unexpected. The Auditor‐General further said:
These issues include:
. agreeing on a timeframe for progressing to a competitively neutral environment;
. the examination of the application of the regulatory framework to ensure that it is consistent with creating a competitively neutral environment for CCMs and EAA;
. establishing arrangements for monitoring and reporting functions detailed in the Act; and
. agreeing on the funding arrangements.

There is some disagreement between the departments and the Auditor-General about the state of that matter. I cannot come down either way. All I can do is commend members of the Senate to look at the report and not simply rely on Senator Carr's misleading misinterpretation of it. The Auditor-General then says:
The non-resolution of these issues creates a risk to the establishment of a competitively neutral environment.

The non‐resolution of these issues over two years by the previous incompetent, hopeless Labor government that Senator Carr has just praised to the skies creates, says the Auditor-General, `a risk to the establishment of a competitively neutral environment'. He further says:

As well, an independent evaluation of competitive arrangements was scheduled to commence in the 1996‐97 Budget context (that is, reported in June 1997). Arrangements need to be progressed sufficiently and agreement reached on the basic issues to ensure the maximum value is gained from this evaluation.

Here we have the Auditor-General posing some problems that need to be resolved but, after two years of Labor, have not been resolved. When you listen to a Senator Carr statement, you would think that there is no such problem whatsoever. It is just incredible that any senator would come into this chamber and seek to mislead it in the way in which Senator Carr has mislead it on this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to this Australian National Audit Office report; hopefully I will have the chance to speak to it in more detail next time it is listed in the Notice Paper . I would like to make a few brief statements about recommendation No. 4. It is an example of the complexity which exists within the system of case management and why it is extremely difficult to implement competition policy in relation to such a system. There are two reasons for that that I can think of immediately.

BREAK.PARA: Firstly, it is not unreasonable that you should base your funding for case management on what you are reasonably expecting to be the outcome of the program. For instance, you could say, `Case management is a useful thing to have. This is how many people require case management, and we can try to make a reasonable estimate of what is required to provide that service.' Unfortunately, that does not tend to be what happens at the moment. Bit by bit we are being told by people involved with case management that they are being offered less and less and that they are being asked to try to produce more and more outcomes. The general principle should be that, if we are saying that case management is a good thing to have, funding should enable those people providing case management to provide the service that they are being asked to provide.

Secondly, can you make a cost comparison between one service and another? The answer is: talk to the people who provide services and talk to the people to whom those services are being provided. The Australian National Audit Office mentions on a number of occasions the phrase `recommended that the stakeholders involved'. The real stakeholders in this issue are not the organisations providing case management, they are the people who are hoping to gain enough training or experience or confidence to get back into the work force or to get into the work force for the first time. Unfortunately, they are generally left out of the process.

The approach taken by providers—even private providers—of case management is often different. Quite frankly, the allocation of cases to case managers, whether they are in the private or public system, often reflects that. They know that particular types of services are able to provide particular types of specialties. There is often a mix as well. The approach taken depends on the region of Australia concerned. Some approaches work in some areas whilst different approaches work better in others.

All along, in relation to employment and training, we have heard from providers and from unemployed people that if you try to make a direct comparison on a dollar‐for‐ dollar basis, you will miss the point entirely. You have to look at outcomes and you have to have the flexibility to understand that some approaches in some areas will cost more because of the whole nature of the issues involved in those areas—the people, the types of training available in those areas, and the types of general employment opportunities available in those areas.

If we drop to the level of competition policy in every area of service provision, we are going to get into deep problems. I believe this is one of those areas where outcomes should be first priority. We should obviously look at the resources that are available to achieve those outcomes, but we have to have a reasonable idea of what we are trying to achieve and how we can best achieve those outcomes.

Therefore, this is not an easy issue. It is time that we all took the opportunity of consulting the people who are providing services and also consulting the people for whom those services are being provided. Quite frankly, the people who are out in the private sector trying to provide those services are being told nothing at the moment about either skillshare or case management—about the future of what they are trying to implement. It is really not good enough.

In the future, I will be taking the opportunity of adding to my remarks today, but there are a whole lot of issues involved with the way we are providing such things as case management, the funding we provide for case management and the basis on which we are assessing case management.
I really do not think that simply judging this on a narrow competition policy basis is going to be a particularly successful outcome. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know there is other business to be done today so I will not delay the Senate. This is a very important document and one that goes very much to the issue of public policy. It deals with the tendering out of services to outside bodies by government. The Industry Commission has produced a report which I think deserves a full-scale debate at the appropriate time.

SPEECH.PARA: The commission says that there has been evidence of considerable savings by the contracting out of services that were previously supplied by government. One of the conclusions it reaches is this. It says on page 555:
The available evidence on the sources of the cost savings from contracting is mixed. It appears that the cost savings may be due to a combination of productivity improvements—
which, of course, we would all agree to—
the use of better combinations of the factors of production, and transfers . . .

This is the worrying issue, because the transfers come mainly from labour. It is a matter of concern that public services may be made cheaper at the cost of proper remuneration to those that carry them out.

The Industry Commission is somewhat tentative in the conclusions it reaches, and it says that people interested in this area should look for further empirical evidence about all these matters. If we are gaining benefits from contracting out—that seems to be the situation, from what the Industry Commission says, and it is a report that everybody should read—at the expense of reduced wages and conditions, then I think it is a matter that we ought to have some concern about.
There are many issues that are raised by this document. As I say, I do not want to

BREAK.PARA: delay the Senate, but it is a document which should not be lightly put aside by this chamber. If I may say so, I picked out that particular issue of proper remuneration for people that carry out services which the public generally need as I thought it would be of some interest to you, Mr Acting Deputy President Childs. For example, the report goes into the issue of hospitals and supply of medical services and what have you. If we are getting those basic services carried out at a cost which is unreasonable, then that is a matter for great pity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—

(a) notes the overwhelming Australian and overseas evidence that the majority of Australian workers will be disadvantaged by the Government's proposals to reform Australia's industrial relations system; and

(b) condemns the Government for continually failing to acknowledge women's concerns in particular, whilst defending the `rock solid' guarantee of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that no worker will be worse off.

It is a pleasure to be able to move this motion today because a matter of significant national pride for me has been the way in which our unique industrial relations system has provided a fair balance between the rights of employers and employer organisations and the rights of workers and trade unions. The way in which our system has protected the rights of workers with limited bargaining power has meant that workers in this country such as shop assistants can earn a living wage for their families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you reading this?

—I have copious notes. That is a very cheap point, I should note. Let me repeat: the way in which our system in Australia has provided a living wage for workers such as shop assistants has been a matter of pride for me. This is not like the environment that has applied, for instance, with the working poor in the United States where 11 million workers are on a minimum rate of an Australian equivalent of $5.30 per hour. This leads to the situation where a family of four with two adult wage earners working full time would only marginally be above the poverty line.

SPEECH.PARA: The other concerning element of the political climate with respect to industrial relations in the United States is the attitude towards trade unions and worker representation and collective organisation. I was able to witness this in around 1991 in a visit to the United States, post the `Justice for janitors' campaign, where janitors in the United States, on very reduced hourly rates of pay, saw no other alternative but to take collective action. The unfortunate component of that collective action was a violent response by police in Los Angeles. This is action you would not expect in this day and age. The crisis developed because a pregnant woman miscarried because of her mistreatment by police. I hope that Australia will not go down this path.

The government's proposals are fundamentally flawed because they ignore the unequal bargaining power between employers and employees. They ignore the unequal position between that pregnant janitor and her multinational employer. Under the guise of promoting cooperative workplace relations, these proposals weaken the protections for workers whilst boosting the flexibility for the employer. Let me flesh out some of these issues.

The government's focus is on cooperation. I applaud that, but they see cooperation as being versus the principles of dispute prevention and settlement. They ignore disputation and they ignore inequality. Let me refer to some comments made by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Reith. In describing the proposals, he said that they represent:

. . . a break with a system of industrial relations that has been based on a view that conflict between employer and employee is fundamental to the relationship and that an adversarial process of resolving disputes is appropriate and inevitable.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is your view, isn't it?
—I will expand upon that point. Mr Reith also said that the proposals reject:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the highly paternalistic presumption that has underpinned the industrial relations system in this country for too long—that employees are not only incapable of protecting their own interests, but even of understanding them, without the compulsory involvement of unions and industrial tribunals.

Let me flesh out these points. Would Mr Reith have similar views about our legal system or our Westminster parliamentary system? Both of these are adversarial and ironically consistent, I would argue, with his parliamentary conduct. My own view, some would argue despite my profession of social work, which is often argued incapable of dealing with conflict situations, is that cooperation is best fostered by acknowledging diverging interests and conflict as well as mutual interests, not by a system that pretends that conflict or diverging interests simply don't exist.

The government view on the need for protection is to ignore that disadvantage exists. At least yesterday Senator Herron had the good grace to acknowledge a different position with respect with Aboriginals and Pauline Hanson's comments. The government view on flexibility is to ignore the question of flexibility for whom or for whose benefit. They talk of choice simplicity; the rhetoric goes on and on. As I shall demonstrate, no case for the benefits for workers has been put. A rock solid guarantee is, in fact, empty.

Over 61,000 accesses to the Internet home page of the Department of Industrial Relations have been made in recent times. The Secretary to the Department of Industrial Relations, David Rosalky, says that the clear interest in the bill reflects that access to it is eagerly anticipated in the private sector, the public sector, academia and even some overseas interests. What about the concerned parties? Don't they exist or don't they know how to access the Internet? Surely some of those 61,000 people are actually concerned about the implications of this bill. The minister is also in fairyland, with recent comments describing the changes such as these:

Because awards will be simplified, there will be more choice about how work is to be organised at the workplace. With simplified awards, employers and employees will find themselves talking to each other more about how they would like to organise, to their mutual benefit, matters that, until now, have been dictated to them by the award.

Has nobody heard of managerial prerogative? How do we prevent dictating to workers how their work will be organised? We only have to look at outworking in the textile clothing industry to see exploitation of women and their families in the name of flexible homework. Ask these workers about Mr Reith's notion of choice and mutual benefit.

I am sure that some commentators are wondering whether Mr Howard's rocks from his rock solid guarantee are actually in his head. Naivety or stupidity have been words used to describe elements of the government's proposals, but the government's limited response to date to the numerous genuine concerns raised has led some to wonder whether duplicity is a more accurate description.

This motion focuses on women in particular because women have generally relied on the protections stemming from our system of arbitration and awards than have men. This is because women are more likely to work in low skill and low wage jobs, with little industrial muscle, and to be employed on a part-time or casual basis. Our system has delivered for women. The industrial relations system has played a significant role in reducing the gender gap in award wages through the equal pay cases of 1969, 1972 and since 1989 in adjusting minimum rates of pay for the low paid through supplementary payments and flat wage increases.

The award system has resulted in higher female to male wage ratios than in other comparable countries, Australia being second only to Sweden. Test cases through the commission have been an important vehicle for introducing employment conditions into awards such as maternity and family leave and how we will do this in the future. There is already considerable evidence that an overly deregulated labour market is not desirable for women. Recent Western Australian, Victorian and New Zealand evidence on wage equity has clearly shown this. Research across the OECD finds that pay equity depends more on a centralised wage fixing system than, in fact, on enactment of equal employment opportunity legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —See if you can do two sentences without reading. At least pretend you're not reading it.

—Let me refer to some of the detailed concerns about a move away from the centralised wage fixing system, such as removing protections for part‐time workers. Most awards provide a minimum number of hours per week for part‐timers in order to ensure that they are given reasonable work opportunities and income. The removal of the requirement that part‐timers be given a minimum number of hours would allow them to be employed for as little as one hour per week. I am not being hypothetical here. There are examples of Victorian contracts where companies such as Toys R Us have sought to introduce one‐hour minimum starts for part‐time workers. Also, hours could vary from week to week so that income stability is lost while the weekly child‐care costs remain essentially the same.

SPEECH.PARA: Consistency in rostering arrangements for part‐time employees with family responsibilities is crucial. The removal of requirements for a set number of hours, and notice in advance if this is to be changed, will be disastrous for many of the women who are currently juggling work and family responsibilities.

Another area of concern is restricting access to federal awards. Access will be restricted for the vast number of women workers in industries which have traditionally been covered by state awards in states such as Victoria where standards have been significantly reduced. These are areas such as clerical, retail, hospital and health workers, many of whom are women.

With respect to workplace agreements, under the current legislation there are significant protections for employees in the enterprise bargaining process, such as measuring agreements against existing awards in order to determine whether employees are disadvantaged. From my own experience I can say there have been enough problems in introducing enterprise bargaining in areas such as the retail industry, which have a significant number of women workers, without those protections also being removed. The government is proposing that agreements be measured only against a set of minimum standards which leave out significant award entitlements.

Let me make some further comments on the issue of equal pay. The federal Labor government acted in 1994 to introduce powers for the commission to remedy instances of discriminatory over‐award payments and the government proposes to remove those. The government claims that adequate provisions are in place through the anti‐discrimination bodies such as the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, despite the comments by the commissioner herself and also despite provisions in the Industrial Relations Act which allow alternative remedies to be used before referring to the act, if such remedies are regarded as reasonable.

PARA.BREAK: The commission is the appropriate body for dealing with these pay related issues. It has the knowledge and the accessible procedures that give the provisions clout, as evidenced by successful settlement of claims under the provisions there to date. The ACTU, utilising these provisions, has had some major successes in negotiating—not arbitrating—the removal of clearly discriminatory over‐award pay ments, especially among female process workers in the manufacturing industry. These are all the types of concerns that have been raised by women's organisations, Labor academics, church and community groups who are alarmed by the changes that are likely to occur.

SPEECH.PARA: These are the concerns which led 47 of the 49 women represented at the national women's organisation round table discussions with Minister Newman to raise several concerns in areas where they believe the bill should be amended. These concerns were as follows, and I hope you do not mind if I read at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't stopped so far.
—It states:

SPEECH.PARA: An equal remuneration clause, so that the equal pay is a requirement in the above award areas of remuneration;
That some provision be made for scrutiny of Australian workplace agreements prior to signing and filing by either the Industrial Relations Commission or the Employment Advocate;
That public access be allowed to workplace agreements after signing;

The maintenance of award conditions such as paid maternity leave, predictable hours and days of work, equal employment opportunity, affirmative action, workplace harassment clause and superannuation arrangements;
The maintenance of paid rates awards for each specific industry and position;
And that some provisions be made for adequate consultation with employees and identified disadvantaged groups, in particular, for certified enterprise agreements.

But to date, even women members of the government have remained silent. Only one female coalition senator has indicated interest in participating in the Senate inquiry into this bill. I am pleased to note that Senator Patterson is going to participate in this debate and has recently arrived in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because our men are interested in it.
—I am very pleased that you will be participating here and now.
—They don't take sides. They are interested in it as well.

—This is a compliment, Senator Patterson. The main point of all this is that the government simply is not listening. Let me give an example of how the government is not listening. As I said, last week 47 of 49 women attending the national women's organisation round table discussions—chaired all day by the minister—signed a petition seeking several changes to the bill. But what was the government's response? The government's response was this document, which we presume was prepared by baby animals. It is headed `How the Workplace Relations Bill will assist women.' If you look at it, there is nothing in this whole document which shows anything which will assist women, not even a rhetorical discussion about how something might assist women. It says:

BREAK.PARA: A strong emphasis is placed on the development of work practices which allow for a better balancing of work and family responsibilities.

Okay, it has strong emphasis. How? It does not say. It talks about the employment advocate who will pay particular attention to providing support for young women and people of non-English speaking backgrounds. But again, how? It does not say. It does not describe how it might occur. It says that awards will continue to provide a safety net, fair minimum wages and conditions for all employees. It says that awards will continue. That is not new assistance.

It talks further—again—about the development of mutually beneficial work practices with employers, about the benefits of this for workers with family responsibilities. But it does not talk about what is going to happen when things are not mutually beneficial. There are no protections there. There is also talk about the benefits for part-time workers, who will have reasonable predicability as to hours worked. It does not tell us in any way at all, though, how this reasonable predicability is going to be guaranteed.

To highlight this document, there is not one single description in these new proposals of how assistance will be rendered to women. All they talk about is how things are going to be continued or how they may be maintained.

Perhaps a worse example, which will highlight why the government needs to be condemned in this area, is yesterday's performance by the member for Dickson, Mr Tony Smith. I do not know whether senators have had the opportunity to read his speech, but even the member for Mackellar, Mrs Bishop, had the courtesy to interject on his comments yesterday.

Mr Smith wanted to look at some practical examples of how the bill will affect women. He claimed that people from our side never do that. He said that half of them have never been in a workplace situation. Perhaps this is the time for me to answer the comments by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) about how many union hacks there are on this side of the chamber. I presume that he is counting me as one of them.

I would have to say that I do have private sector experience. I worked in the retail industry before I worked for the union. I suppose it would be a bit of a worry to be a hack at the age of 34. I doubt whether I am stereotypical of what the government claims the union movement represents at the moment. So I am not quite sure how he classes people on this side when he talks about people working in industrial relations and being union hacks. I am also a social worker by profession and have worked in that industry as well. So, if he is classing me as a trade union hack, he might want to look at how he is assessing people, because there are several other areas in which he could class my background as well.

Let us go back to Tony Smith. He said that he was an article clerk and started work with a female. Good heavens! Everybody knows that an article clerk is a general dogs body. He said that he had equal pay but that it was not equal work. Whenever heavy lifting, carrying or anything of a heavy nature had to be done, guess who had to do it? The males had to do it.

I wonder whether Mr Tony Smith would suggest that I should not have had full senatorial pay during the period that I was not able to lift heavy weights. Did that affect my performance, I wonder. Maybe a pregnant woman should not be in this House, according to the way he classes these things.

The synopsis of my comments here today, though, is to point out that the government to date has provided no evidence of benefits for workers in its workplace relations proposals. It has found no evidence to date that this sort of deregulation will provide any benefits for workers.

The main people who will be disadvantaged, of course, are the workers who are already disadvantaged in the work force. The predominant number of those are women. We on this side say that the government needs to be condemned for the proposals in this. Whilst their rhetoric is that they are doing things for women and women with family responsibilities, there has to date been no substance to those claims. They have not been able to demonstrate clearly how any of their claims will provide improvements for women or women with family responsibilities. I commend the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised that this is the motion that we are debating in the general business of the Senate today. I happened to be in the chamber in the middle of the afternoon yesterday when Senator Jacinta Collins sought leave to introduce this motion. It shows you just how well organised they on the other side are when it comes to the general run of business.

SPEECH.PARA: After a little bit of discussion, it was decided that this should be today's general business. It is part of the process that they are now going through in the lead-up to the introduction of the workplace reform bill into this place and its consequent examination by the economics committee over a period of time in July.
Senator Collins did not read the motion—she read it yesterday. We ought to understand what we are debating today. Senator Collins moved:
That the Senate—

(a) notes the overwhelming Australian and overseas evidence that the majority of Australian workers will be disadvantaged by the Government's proposals to reform Australia's industrial relations system . . .

I did not hear much about that in Senator Collins's speech. She condemned the government for continually failing to acknowledge in particular women's concerns while defending the rock-solid guarantee of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that no worker will be worse off. The government has been in power now for 16 weeks. If you think that for 16 weeks we have continually denied women's rights, then you have been in a different place from me.

I have to say that I had no objection to Senator Collins reading her contribution today. It is the same old contribution that we have heard year after year and time after time from people on the other side when it comes to industrial relations matters. You would want to make sure that you got it right. If I were you, I would keep reading it too, because nobody over this side, no matter how many times you tell us, will believe the things that you were trying to express today in moving this motion.

You started off by saying that our industrial relations system is unique. It is unique all right. You have run it for 13 years. Any changes that have been made to our industrial relations legislation in the past 13 years have been made by the members opposite. After 13 years people finished up being worse off than they were when you started in this government 13 years ago. That is your record in industrial relations.

So you are right: our system is unique. That is why we are going to change it. What we want to do is make sure that the workers and the employers in Australia have a better system to operate under, one which will make both better off. Up until now that has just never happened. It never will happen unless we make some changes and introduce some choice into the system that we already have.
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Ferguson has got the call.
—I was starting to wonder about that, Mr Acting Deputy Presi dent. We were reasonably quiet while we let Senator Collins read her speech.
—You said that she was reading her speech.

—I did not object to her reading her speech, did I, Senator Evans? She also used some comparisons with the United States on a couple of very special issues. If we are going to talk about overseas evidence that the majority of Australian workers will be disadvantaged by our proposals, you could look further than those few very narrow examples you used with regard to the experience overseas. I am not quite sure that the old saying `Comparisons are odious' does not apply to some of the comparisons that you used.

SPEECH.PARA: You also talked about people on this side using rhetoric. If anybody ought to talk about using rhetoric when it comes to industrial relations, we need look no further than those senators sitting on the opposite side of the chamber. We have heard nothing but rhetoric for 13 years, probably nothing but rhetoric since 1893—my history is not that good but I think the labour movement started in about 1893. We hear the same old rhetoric year after year about protecting the worker, looking after the disadvantaged. In fact the rhetoric that you use has never been put into practice, and you proved that over the 13 years when you did nothing to improve the lot of the workers in Australia between 1983 and 1996.

You can continue to use that rhetoric because, as Senator Alston said today, many of you have never been in the real world of taking a risk. The risk takers are the people of Australia who will make this country thrive or not; they are the small business people. Under your government those people were continually taking a risk. You have done nothing.

I want to reiterate that the risk takers in this world are those small business people in Australia for whom you have made life so difficult. I can give you a number of examples of people who have been in small business over a period of time who used to be employers. Many of those people are no longer employers. They will do what they can do working on their own, without employing anybody else, because they are not prepared to take the risk because of the unfair dismissal laws that you put into place, because of the amount of red tape that goes with employing. You can talk about the large businesses and the people who might employ 20, 30 or 40 people or more, but let me tell you this: those people who used to employ one or two people no longer wish to employ.

If you wanted me to, I could cite a number of examples in my own home town of 1,000 people where there are at least four builders who now work on their own or with each other. They do not employ one person, whereas they used to employ 15 people between them until 1983. So, if you have been in the real world and taken the risks, you will understand the difficulties that you will find under the current industrial legislation and the impediments there are to employing people.

Senator Collins also mentioned the outworkers inquiry, which we are currently in the middle of and hope to report on soon. Let me say just one thing: those outworkers that you say are so disadvantaged have all been disadvantaged under your legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your industrial relations.

—They have been disadvantaged under all the industrial relations mechanisms you have put in place. Not one of those current predicaments is the responsibility of this current government. I concede that we have discovered throughout our inquiry—although we have not reported yet, I think it is fair to say—many situations which are quite unsatisfactory. They are just as unsatisfactory to people on this side of the chamber as they are to people on your side of the chamber.
—So let's improve it rather than make it worse.

—We will improve it for them—do not worry about that. You had 13 years. Why didn't you improve it in 13 years? You never improved it one little bit. It has got worse under you, Senator Neal. You are the ones who had the legislation. So let us not talk about the workers who are currently disadvantaged under your legislation because one thing the current legislation will mean is greater freedom of choice to all Australians as they go about their daily work.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons this bill has been put into place is that currently we have what you could call a highly paternalistic presumption that has underpinned our industrial relations system in this country for too long. That assumption is that employees are incapable of protecting their own interests or of even understanding them without the compulsory involvement of unions or industrial tribunals. That just simply is not the case. There are many employees in Australia who would like to conduct their own affairs and make their own arrangements.
I have been an employer in the past, only of one or two people, in our own farming enterprise. There was never a need for anybody to help the understanding between us and our working men.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us their names and we will ring them up and check.

—Yes, you can. Senator Neal, I would be very pleased to give you the name. The last person that I employed, and I can tell you quite personally, started working with us at age 45. We treated him so badly that he retired at age 65, and he is now at age 80. We still keep in regular contact with him. Not once at any stage during that working career did he or my brother and I ever have any dispute over wages or gave any consideration to it. We always ensured that that person got paid far and above the award which was set in place.
—Is he the only person you have ever employed?
—No, we have employed three other people plus some shearers. Shearers were paid under award wages.
—Under‐award wages?

—No, under the award conditions. Thank you, Senator Forshaw—you would understand. Shearers were paid either under the award conditions or above award payments. The other people who were employed were always employed at above the award arrangements that were in place.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill that is currently before the House of Representatives, and the one that will be introduced into this place, in contrast to the legislation that you have tinkered with over the past 13 years, seeks to restore the focus of the system on those who really matter—that is, the employees and the employers. They are the ones who really matter at the workplace and enterprise level.

That is something you have never been able to do. You have tried to. You have attempted to. Your own previous Prime Minister was quite concerned and reached the stage where enterprise bargaining was to take place. We have reached the situation where we believe employees should have the right to make their own arrangements if they so choose.

In 1993 the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, said that Australia needed a model of industrial relations `which places primary emphasis on bargaining at the workplace level within a framework of minimum standards'. That is exactly what is proposed by the current government. He went on to say:
Over time the safety net would inevitably become simpler.
These are the words of your great hero, the former Prime Minister, Paul Keating.

If anyone has any doubts about the need for genuine reform in industrial relations—reform of its institutions and arrangements—they need go no further than the ABS statistics which show that we still have the intolerable unemployment rate of 8.9 per cent, with the rate of youth unemployment at just under 30 per cent. If ever there was an indictment of 13 years of Labor rule, it is in the area of unemployment, and much of it can be attributed to the inflexible working arrangements that you put in place. In many instances, they led to employers not being prepared to employ people. They chose instead to work as hard as they could without the use of employed labour in order to make a living.

The motion refers to the `overwhelming evidence' that the majority of Australian workers will be disadvantaged by the proposed legislation. If you have already reached that conclusion—I see that Senator Jacinta Collins has left the chamber—it seems there is no real need for the political junket we are going on. I refer to the inquiry in July that will look at such things as: the implications of the bill for our economy; whether the provisions of the bill will fulfil our international obligations; and the effect of similar provisions in other countries. I do not know how much we are expected to fit into the 18 or so days of this inquiry but if we were to go into detail on all those matters we would not be reporting on 22 August 1996, we would be reporting on 22 August 1998.

The impact on small business of the proposed legislation is one area where we will receive plenty of evidence. The people who feel most disadvantaged by the legislation put in place by the former government are the small businesses in this country. The people in this chamber who understand small business best are those sitting on this side because many of us have been involved in small business and know the difficulties that exist. There are other things besides industrial relations matters that impact on small business but it is having the biggest effect.

Another aspect of this inquiry is to determine whether the bill in whole or in part is constitutional. Why on earth would the economics committee be looking at whether a bill is constitutional when we have a legal and constitutional committee in the Senate. This was debated at length when the committee's terms of reference were before the Senate but I still cannot understand why an economics committee should be investigating whether a bill in whole or in part is constitutional.

There are many other speakers on this side who wish to speak on this motion so I do not intend to take up much more time. In conclusion, I say to senators opposite that they would do well to read some of the newspaper articles that have appeared the past couple of months and which have been written by people of various political leanings. There was an article today by Judith Sloan about the work of this committee and I could do no better than to quote her conclusion. She writes:

BREAK.PARA: The Australian taxpayer would have been much better served if the Bill had been considered, as it should have been, by a Senate legislation committee.
I am pleased that Judith Sloan wrote that. It is the very argument we put forward in this place some months ago when it was first suggested that this bill be sent to a references committee.

Senator Collins's motion referred to evidence from Australia and overseas that workers would be disadvantaged. I am yet to see that evidence. I find it difficult to believe that any inquiry will take overseas evidence. I certainly reject the assertions contained in this motion. It was obviously cobbled together late yesterday just so there would be something to debate in general business today. I would have thought that the time for giving notices of motion would have provided a better debating arena.

I certainly reject the assertion in this motion that Australian workers will be disadvantaged. That is simply not the case. As for the suggestion that we continue to fail to acknowledge women's concerns, let me say that people on this side of the chamber treat everyone equally. Women's concerns and men's concerns will receive equal consideration under any legislation that comes into this place from this government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a motion by Senator Jacinta Collins relating to the government's proposals to change the industrial relations system in Australia. The first part of the motion refers to `overwhelming Australian and overseas evidence that the majority of Australian workers will be disadvantaged by the government's proposals to reform Australia's industrial relations system.' There is a couple of ways of looking at that.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, there is recognition, even by supporters of this bill in the media and elsewhere, that the bill is designed to shift the bargaining power from workers and their representatives to employers. Those people who advocate this change believe that that is a fair change. I do not happen to agree with that, but there is a recognition that that is the nature of the proposed changes that will be implemented if this bill is passed as presented. If you go along with those advocates of the change in the system who say that the thrust of the bill is to change the relative bargaining power away from workers and their representatives to employers and business in general, then what are we looking at? Who, in this system, our current system, is in a strong or even an equal bargaining position?

Let me work backwards from here. Are the young in a strong or equal bargaining position? No. Clearly, that is not the case. They do not have a great deal of information, they do not have a great deal of confidence and they are new to the system. Standing up for your rights is provably very difficult, if not impossible, if you are young and looking for a job—or even if you are young, trained and working in the system. Are the unskilled in our society, male and female, in a strong or equal bargaining position? Clearly, that is not the case. If it was the case, then we would not have to put clauses into legislation to make sure that those people are advised, or, as in previous legislation, make sure that those people are asked their opinion. Are migrants, people who have English as a second language or people who have no real understanding of their rights under the system in a strong or even equal bargaining position? Clearly, that is not the case. Clearly, such issues as have come out through the outworkers inquiry give an indication that it is that sector of employees who really are getting the rotten end of any stick in relation to our current industrial relations system. Are people who are still unemployed and looking for a job in a strong or equal bargaining position? Quite frankly, ask most unemployed people and they would say no, their bargaining position is not very strong. And it looks like it is going to get worse, especially if they apply for a job or send for a job application and they are handed terms and conditions of employment which they know—even with inexperience—are not fair. The proposal from this government is that that employer be encouraged to dob you in to take you off unemployment.

Basically, that very low bargaining power is getting worse. What about remote area employees? What real chance would a person living in a remote area, where everybody knows each other, have of inviting a union into a workplace if everybody knows them and if their employer happens to be against union involvement—now or in the future—or if there is a change of power arrangement where they think they can get away with that?

What about the issue of women in the work force? We are not talking about a minority group in our society. We are talking about 50 per cent of the population. Are women in the work force generally in a strong or equal bargaining position? Clearly, no, and that has been the concern of many people in relation to industrial relations. Do you judge the nature of your industrial relations system on what a good employer may do to people who have confidence, knowledge and a good bargaining position? The answer is no. You cannot base an industrial relations system on that kind of mechanism or that kind of scenario, because it is clearly not realistic.

I would like to now concentrate on the issue raised in the second part of Senator Jacinta Collins's motion in relation to women because it highlights the fact that this government is pursuing workplace changes without giving any consideration to the impacts that those changes have on the lives of workers. What have we been told by the new government? We have been told by the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, that no worker will be worse off.

Women have been fighting for equity in the workplace for decades. What a revolutionary concept! Just imagine the gall of these people, half the population, actually suggesting that anyone who is employed on work of equal value should expect equal pay! It is a sad indictment of our society that, so many years after the suffragettes fought for the right to vote, their granddaughters and great‐granddaughters are still fighting for equality in the workplace. Unfortunately, the government's workplace reforms will place women back in a similar position to their grandmothers, and it appears that the coalition is comfortable with this return to the past.

Let me talk about a few of the concerns that have been forwarded to me in relation to these issues. I quote from a letter from Women in Industry and Community Health. This is a migrant women's association. They are happy that there have been some amendments to the workplace relations bill as a result of some of their concerns. However, they are concerned that many problems still remain, in particular:
* the narrowing of the definition of equal pay to include only minimum award pay instead of whole pay.

* the stripping of awards to a bare minimum number of provisions, removing such conditions as paid maternity leave, predictable hours and days of work, EEO, affirmative action and workplace harassment clauses, and superannuation arrangement.
They say:
In view of the bargaining power of women in general, leaving it to women to bargain back these entitlements at a workplace level via agreements—
they believe—
is a very poor option;
They are concerned about:

. . . the active promotion of secret non-union individual agreements (Australian Workplace Agreements, or AWAs) as the basis for employment conditions, such agreements not being open to public scrutiny, whether by unions or the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC), by anti‐discrimination bodies or even by workers in the same workplace . . .
What kind of equal bargaining power is that? There is no indication that we are talking about equal bargaining power here. They are concerned about:

. . . the absence of any scrutiny by the Office of Employment Advocate prior to certification of an Australian AWA agreement to ensure that it meets the minimum safety net standards set out in the Bill;
They are concerned that:
. . . the reduction of the safety net standard the AIRC is to apply in the case of union‐negotiated agreements . . .
And they are concerned about:
. . . the removal of special requirements to consult with and inform disadvantaged groups in the workplace (e.g. women, people of non English speaking background, young people)—
part of the list that I was reading before—

BREAK.PARA: about a proposed workplace agreement before it is finalised . . .
What kind of choice is it when you get given a workplace agreement of which you have had no part in compiling? What kind of choice is it to say no in those kinds of circumstances?

They are concerned about the abolition of paid rates awards and their replacement with minimum rates awards and the fact that many women work under paid rates awards, including those in community services, health and education. They are concerned that the abolition of paid rates awards in those areas will lead to a reduction over time in pay to those areas and to an increase in the gender gap in Australia. We know it exists already, but they are concerned about the increase in this gap.

They believe that those changes go far beyond any changes that were mentioned by the coalition during the election campaign. In relation to that, a number of media commentators—who think that these new reforms may be the best thing since sliced bread, especially for business—have commented in sheer outrage that the Senate should dare to consider that these issues are important enough to be looked at carefully and should be properly taken to the community for their comment and response.

Let me remind you that the removal of the discrimination provisions was not foreshadowed before the election. The elimination of the requirement for inserting the model anti‐discrimination clause was not foreshadowed. The limitation on conditions that awards can cover was not foreshadowed or specified. There were no changes foreshadowed to the equal pay legislation prior to the election. The only reference to equal pay was that it would be a minimum condition for Australian workplace agreement. Of course, this hardly seems to be the case if you are only talking about minimum awards. Removal of the requirement for award reviews to address discrimination was not foreshadowed.

Basically what we are talking about is a whole lot of areas. We are talking about delays in sick pay—not foreshadowed; changes to supported wage provision—not foreshadowed; eliminating the requirement to consult with employees who may be disadvantaged—not foreshadowed; eliminating the requirement that agreements not be discriminatory—not foreshadowed; elimination of single bargaining unit provisions and provisions for multi-employer and multi-union certificate agreements—not foreshadowed; the removal of protection against discriminatory dismissal—not foreshadowed—and it was said that there were to be changes to that agreement; and the imposition of filing fees—not foreshadowed.

They are concerned that the system will be problematic for disadvantaged groups, including women.
