Their weaker bargaining position and the lack of knowledge and support and representation available to them are going to be real challenges for the system to overcome. The role of the AIRC in protecting the interests and concerns of vulnerable groups needs to be ensured. They believe that a pro‐active role of up‐front checking of awards and agreements as well as complaint provisions offers the best option for doing that. They believe, and I agree, that the operations of the industrial relations system should be opened to the public. Knowledge and analysis of how it is operating should be made available.

As I say, if you are looking at any industrial relations system, you have to ask the questions: who has bargaining power? How will that bargaining power change? What will the possible outcomes be? Because of those questions and because of the information I have given today, I believe the concerns that are being expressed today in Senator Jacinta Collins's motion are real. The Greens support those concerns and believe that the process that we are going through in talking to the people of Australia will bring some of those out but not all of them, because you conceivably will not have the time to bring all of those out. Quite frankly, there is a lot of interest in the community about these issues. If the government is not listening to those concerns and it is not prepared to change its proposals in relation to those concerns, the proposals do not deserve to be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the election, John Howard said that no worker would suffer a cut in take- home pay as a result of the coalition's reforms. He has made a mockery of this statement already. The general business motion today is this:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—

(a) notes the overwhelming Australian and overseas evidence that the majority of Australian workers will be disadvantaged by the Government's proposals to reform Australia's industrial relations system; and

(b) condemns the Government for continually failing to acknowledge women's concerns in particular, whilst defending the `rock solid' guarantee of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that no worker will be worse off.

The changes proposed by the coalition are attacks on workers, pure and simple. They are in the same vein as attacks on workers in the United States, in Britain, in New Zealand, in Western Australia and in Queensland. What is worse, these attacks will particularly affect the people who are in the weakest position in our society: workers in industries which have a majority of women, part-time workers and workers in helping professions.

Members of the Liberal Party in recent times have prided themselves in the number of women on their back bench. I applaud any increase in the number of women in our parliaments, but I am amazed and dismayed that these women are prepared to capitulate to the leaders of this government and allow this leadership to attack the industrial relations in this country, particularly to attack women workers. The women in this parliament, by not taking this up on the government side, have sold out their sisters.

The evidence we have collected over the years shows that women do better under a centralised wage fixation system. Women on awards receive 93.8 per cent of a man's wage. That is the position at the present moment. Yet, in Australia women still receive only 54.7 per cent of the average over‐award payments received by men. That reflects our history.

Women already trail men in over‐award payments. The coalition's legislation will worsen this situation in two major ways: firstly, because over‐award payments will become a matter for negotiation between, in this case, women and their employers—and these negotiations will be recorded in secret workplace deals—and, secondly, because the government intends to remove the Australian Industrial Relations Commission's powers to enforce equality in over‐award payments. That is a vital issue in this debate.

Discrimination in over‐award payments has been addressed by many women's groups and unions and in reports such as the 1990 National Women's Consultative Committee pay equity report and the 1992 Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report Just rewards. Our Labor government acted on these concerns and in 1994 introduced new equal remuneration provisions in part 4A of the Industrial Relations Act. These amendments gave the Industrial Relations Commission the ability to remedy instances of discriminatory effects in over‐award payments.

The ACTU, using these provisions, has been able to ensure women in several key industries are now not disadvantaged in their access to over‐award payments. The coalition government now proposes to remove these amendments, although it said nothing about this during the election. So that is the king hit that this government is going to render to women in this country.

The government claims adequate procedures are in place through anti-discrimination bodies such as the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. If you think about that, it is ridiculous. However, procedures under existing equal opportunity and sex discrimination legislation are complex and lengthy and can only deal with individual injustice. The legislation cannot improve conditions for whole groups of women. That in itself is completely inadequate and the coalition's solution in this case is a fraud on all women workers.

The removal of the Industrial Relations Commission's ability to deal with unfair contracts involving independent contractors will affect women classified as independent contractors or outworkers in industries such as clothing, cleaning, child care and many other clerical and professional areas of work. I have seen, in my role on the Senate economics committee, the effects of these unfair contracts on workers.

BREAK.PARA: The economics committee is currently examining the position of outworkers in the clothing industry in this country. I believe most Australians would be appalled at the exploitation of these workers. I acknowledge that is under the existing law. Industrial law is always subject to the most recent challenges to undercut or undermine standards of conditions in industry.

I welcome the progress that has been made by the unions, employers and retailers in the clothing industry. I certainly hope that when we consider the industrial relations legislation we make sure that the existing protective clauses that are the key to solving the problem in the clothing industry are included in any new legislation and extended.

These people are the most exploited people in our community. They do not have the English language skills to easily complain about their plight. They will be the future of the Australian work force if we are not careful, because what we see in some of the outworker examples is the way the coalition industrial relations policy would work in a whole range of other industries.

Recently, the federal government withdrew funding for a project designed to improve conditions for outworkers. Our Labor government had promised to fund a $400,000 project for outworkers where outworkers were to be informed of their rights and entitlements in their own languages and employers were to be educated about their responsibilities. Three weeks after the election, the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Union was notified that the project had been cancelled. The funding the Labor government had given to the union had gone. The union has been asked to repay funding it has already received.

But not only that. Peter Reith has already said that he will oppose the adoption of a home work convention at the current meeting of the ILO. So it is a consistent pattern, unfortunately, that this government is following—of undermining conditions and, in this case, where you have a problem, making it more difficult for the employers and the unions in that particular industry to solve their problems.
This government's industrial relations proposal will pull the safety net out from under the most vulnerable members of our society who are working. Before the election, John Howard said:

No worker will suffer a cut in take home pay as a result of the coalition's reforms. Employees would be given the choice to remain with the current award system, or a certified agreement, or enter into a workplace agreement . . . We are not going to abolish the award system.

The reality is that paid rates workers will not have the choice of remaining in their awards. This paid rates award issue is a big issue. About 1.7 million Australians work under a paid rates award—about 25 per cent of the Australian work force are on paid rates awards.

What Mr Reith is now proposing is to remove from the Industrial Relations Act the present sections which provide explicitly for the making of paid rates awards. He also proposes to amend the act to prevent the making of paid rates awards. He is talking about blanket action rather than a case by case examination of awards. Each paid rate award would be converted to a minimum rate plus a frozen dollar amount equal to the difference between the minimum and the previous paid rate award.

This means a substantial component of the wages will be frozen in time, never to be readjusted. This could be up to 25 per cent of a worker's pay and conditions. Workers who will be affected include nurses, teachers, police, vehicle manufacturing employees, maritime workers and thousands of others—many people in a whole range of callings.

Let us take nurses for an example of the effect of the proposed changes from paid rates to minimum rates awards. Nurses stand to lose not only pay but also annual leave and career opportunities. They may even lose their rostered days off and safe rosters, leading to greater uncertainty and stress and making regular arrangements such as child care very difficult. The majority of Australian nurses are currently at a grade two level in their profession. A grade two nurse earns about $30,000 per year—little enough for the physically difficult, complex and emotionally draining job that nursing can be. Yet the coalition proposals will drop them even lower down the pay scale.

The Australian Nurses Federation estimates that a grade two nurse will lose up to $150 a week, dropping her to the minimum annual salary of the equivalent of an entry level position of about $23,000. Even if this difference is made up now with a fixed payment of $150 a week, this component of a nurse's wage will not increase unless individual employers decide to give their staff more. With the massive cuts the coalition is proposing to the health budget, the medical employer will not have the means or the inclination to top up nurses' pay because this is one of the industries, if we are to believe the constant rumours floating about, that is going to be devastated by government intervention.

Important as this $150 per week drop in wages is, it is not the only issue for nurses. Nurses value their career structures, professional development and guaranteed access to training very highly. They are covered by the paid rates award. They will not be included in a minimum rates award. That is another area they run the risk of losing which is important to their personal esteem and professional development.

Clerical workers provide another example of the potential loss to workers if the conversion to minimum rates awards proceeds. This industry involves thousands of women. A clerical worker under a paid rate federal award at ASO5, for example, currently earns $37,607. A Victorian clerical worker on an comparable level earns $27,963. That is a 25.6 per cent difference—the equivalent of $185 per week or $9,000‐odd annually. That is the threat to people under those federal awards as a result of this legislation.

It is all very well to say that the workers can negotiate with individual employers for the difference. This is not going to happen in practice. It will definitely not happen in the public sector because the coalition is slashing and burning the public sector. We are being asked to believe that a minimum wages policy like those of the United States or Britain will benefit Australia. Of course it will not, but that is the model the government is looking at. It might provide a short‐term benefit to some employers, but it certainly will not benefit workers.

The benefits of growth in the United States economy have accrued almost exclusively to the top half of the top one per cent of individuals in the United States. That is, multimillionaires are doing better than ever. At the same time, as already mentioned by Senator Jacinta Collins, the debate rages over whether the minimum wage for United States workers will be increased from $US4.25 an hour to $US5.15. That $US4.25 is $A5.70. United States full-time workers on the minimum wage earn $US8,500 per annum.

That amount is not even half the official poverty line for a family of four. About 3.7 million Americans earn the $US4.25 minimum. Another 10 million earn between $US4.25 and $AUS5.15. That is still below the poverty line. The American Democrats want to raise the minimum to $US5.15. Of course, the Republicans in the United States have been resisting that.

Some economists predict disaster, yet recent economic research suggests that raising minimum wages will actually have no effect, or will have only a small positive effect, on employment figures. Certainly employment is not highest where real wages are lowest.

Attacks on workers' minimum conditions have become the order of the day in Britain also. The conservative government—once again, the friends of this government—with the Confederation of British Industry cheering them on, has abolished the £3 per hour minimum rate. We refer in this motion to the common action of conservative governments that this government is now copying.

The only reason why British workers, for the most part, have not experienced the same drop in real wages over the last 15 years as American workers have, is the strength of the trade unions in Great Britain. In the United States, union membership has continued to fall. It is currently one‐eighth of the work force. In both countries the gap between rich and poor continues to widen. These are the examples of conservative governments and the mechanisms that they have applied in industrial relations that this government is trying to introduce into Australia.

Yet despite this evidence from overseas, the coalition government wants to follow these examples and do to Australian workers what has been done to workers overseas. Before the election, the Prime Minister promised that no Australian worker would be worse off under a coalition government. Already the attacks on the weakest have begun, as I have already indicated, and attacks on the unions that protect them have begun. All members of the government instinctively—and they have done it again today; they cannot help themselves—attack the organisations that are there to protect workers.

The coalition's industrial relations policy will isolate and disadvantage those workers who already are most disadvantaged in our community. Social Darwinism is the term best used to describe the coalition's proposals. The strongest will survive and prosper. The weakest will not.

Mr Howard said that no worker would be worse off under his government. Tell that to the nurses around Australia, as I have described the position they face. These are the real examples for the vast majority of nurses in that profession at this moment. That is because of this paid rates award issue.

It is no good talking about negotiation between employers and workers when many of those workers have poor English—in a typical factory where there are 20 or 30 former nationalities represented or people with very poor English all being asked to negotiate with an employer. Of course, that employer always has in this system the access to the legal advice, the access to the knowledge of what is in the industry, the access to every bit of advice—

TALK.START.PARA: —I never had that.

—You weren't typical of the type of company that will determine the rate in a particular industry. A person employing one or two persons—as you might have been as a farmer—will not determine the rate in the industry. But of course, the powerful people in those industries will use that power to undermine the rate. All the decent employ ers in industry who want to do the right thing, like Senator Ferguson, who want to pay a reasonable rate, are undermined by the person who can sign the secret deal and, by using cheaper labour, get under the neck of the person who is doing the right thing.

BREAK.PARA: The government has also told us that their policies will make it easier for employees to blend their family and workplace responsibilities. That is nonsense. It is particularly important that male senators opposite listen to this, because of the threat it represents to a whole range of women. The government proposals to remove the minimum and maximum hours requirement on part-time workers will wreak havoc for workers with family responsibilities. Workers will have no way of knowing whether they will be working one hour this week or 40 hours next week.

Any worker with family responsibilities will tell you how difficult it is to find child care at short notice. It is women particularly, as indicated in this motion, who are going to be affected by that catch-all word that members of the government are using—flexibility. It is flexible, all right—flexible so that women will not know from one day to the next how their child care will be organised. The hours people work have been regulated in a commonsense way. This government is now going to chuck that out the window.

How can a family budget when they have no idea how much money will be coming in from week to week? Talk about the family! That worry, that anxiety, of people losing the ability to have some control over their lives is a problem that particularly affects women because it is a responsibility they often primarily handle.

For all those reasons, I support the motion moved by Senator Jacinta Collins. I believe that as this debate goes on some coalition colleagues will be able to see the error of their ways. Certainly, if they do not they will face the wrath of the Australian people, the working people—particularly women—because there are so many either unintended consequences in the government's proposed legislation or deliberate attempts to take away the fairness that has been a characteristic of our industrial relations system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are seeing this evening in this motion being debated at the behest of Senator Jacinta Collins is the creation, effectively, of a straw man which Senator Collins and her Labor colleagues on the other side in this debate then seek to knock down. That reflects what the Labor Party generally has been doing with regard to the much-needed industrial relations reforms and in particular the workplace relations bill put forward by the new Howard government.

SPEECH.PARA: They are setting up this straw man by making a whole range of false claims about the government's policy and about the effects of this legislation and then they knock down those false claims that they have created. What we are hearing from the Labor Party is a farrago of lies about the government's intentions generally and about this legislation in particular. That should be said at the outset in dealing with this particular motion.
I notice that Senator Jacinta Collins does not seem to be here for the debate. This is her motion, her item on the agenda that is being debated today. Where is she?

TALK.START.PARA: —Not interested

—She is not interested. She made her speech. She has set up the straw man and she has tried to knock it down. Having listened to what she said, she did not even do a very good job of knocking down the straw man that she herself created. Having done that, she is not interested in the rest of the debate. She is not interested in what happens to this motion. She made her speech and she has left the chamber. So much for the bone fides of Senator Jacinta Collins as far as industrial relations matters are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the greatest needs in this country currently is the creation of jobs. We desperately need the creation of more jobs. Where is the greatest potential for job creation in this country?

TALK.START.PARA: —Small business.

—Exactly. You have read my mind, Senator Ferguson. Small business provides the greatest job creation potential in this country. Among small business, one of the sectors that has the greatest potential is the tourism and hospitality industries. It just so happens that last night I was in Adelaide representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, John Moore, at the national excellence awards presentation dinner for the hospitality industry.
—I bet you didn't get one.

—I was not there for that purpose. I was there to present one, and I probably did a reasonable job in doing that. In the course of what were necessarily very brief remarks to that audience, I made the point that the goal of this government in assisting small business, particularly in the hospitality industry, was to get rid of unnecessary regulation and red tape that wears down their capacity to provide services and have efficiency and productivity.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, I highlighted the importance of this government's proposed industrial relations reforms to provide a better, more direct and flexible relationship at the workplace between employers and employees. In the middle of those remarks, I was interrupted by sustained applause and verbal support from that very large audience of small business people in the hospitality industry. Those in the growing hospitality and tourism sector know that this legislation will provide the opportunity for them to create more jobs because of the fact that they will be able to operate more effectively and efficiently. That is hot off the press, first‐hand experience of the benefits that this legislation will provide for job creation in this country.

As I have said, the Labor Party have set up a straw man as far as the legislation is concerned. They are putting out a farrago of lies about this legislation, saying that maternity leave will be removed from awards where it exists; that workers' wages will be cut; that the legislation will apply the principle of equal pay for equal work of equal value only to the base award minimum; that the legislation is an attack on part-time workers and seeks to casualise the work force—we heard that a moment ago from our Labor colleague; that employers will be able to vary the hours for part‐time workers at will; that this legislation involves the removal of restrictions to lessen protections for part‐time workers; and, that federal agreements can be overridden by state agreements. Each one of those propositions is an absolutely false claim.

Those opposite who have spoken on this motion have shown a feigned concern about the position of women under this legislation. Let me remind the Senate what a high priority the labour movement, particularly the trade union movement, places on women's rights: they don't place any priority on it whatsoever. Let me remind the Senate of the actions of Jenny Booth of the textile and clothing workers union when she marched into a clothing factory in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's Anna Booth.

—I apologise, it is Anna Booth. She said, `The arrangements that you, the women workers in this factory, have entered into voluntarily with your employer cannot be allowed to continue. They are breaking down the hard‐won gains of the union movement.' What were those arrangements that had been entered into voluntarily, at the request of the female workers in that factory? The arrangements were to allow them all to start work earlier in the day, to work their normal working hours, and to finish work earlier in the day, so that they could blend together their work and family responsibilities. They would be finished work in time to either pick their children up from school or be at home when their children arrived home from school, thereby meeting both their family and work responsibilities. This agreement was reached at the initiative of those working women.
—They have gone quiet.

—Yes, those opposite become very quiet when they hear the truth. That arrangement was voluntarily entered into and agreed with the employer. In marched Anna Booth who said, `The union will not let you do this. This is breaking down our hard‐won gains.' What absolute nonsense. What were the hard‐won gains? We know they were really the power of the trade union movement. All the trade union movement cares about is its own power and its capacity to manipulate in the workplace. It does not care about the actual circumstances and situations of the workers at all. That is clearly demonstrated by the way it acted in this case.
—And the workers did it by themselves.

—Indeed, they did. They entered into that arrangement voluntarily, at their own request. So much for the concern of the labour movement and the trade unions with regard to women's rights in the workplace in particular. The real concern of the trade union movement is the maintenance of its own power: firstly, to maintain their power as organisations; and, secondly, to maintain the power of their elected officials, who are far distant from the rank and file members who work in enterprises at the coalface. They are all about maintaining their own power.

SPEECH.PARA: We know only too well that the Labor Party in this place and around Australia is merely the creature of the trade union movement. It is the trade union movement that started and established the Labor Party. The Labor Party has always been here to do the bidding of the trade union movement. That is why they set up this straw man and this farrago of lies about the government's proposal. That is exactly what Senator Jacinta Collins has done today in bringing forward this motion for debate. She is doing the trade unions' bidding in trying to undermine this legislation.

This legislation has the trade union movement frightened because it involves some loss of power for them. It will require that trade unions provide real and genuine service to their members; otherwise they will continue to vote with their feet and walk away from the trade union movement in droves, as we have seen happening in recent years, with trade union membership in free fall. Under this legislation, unless trade unions start to provide genuine services for their members, that loss of membership will continue apace. That is what the trade union movement and the Labor Party are frightened about. That is their real motive in wanting to undermine this legislation.

Let us deal further with the labour movement's treatment of women in the workplace, indeed, in the union movement itself—because that is the essential issue that this motion seeks to raise. Despite the fact that, at long last, the trade union movement has a female president, there is no doubt that it is a male dominated institution. Its creature, the Labor Party, has not matched its own rhetoric with regard to female representation in politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who did Martin Ferguson knock off?
—A female candidate, as I recall. In practice, neither the Labor Party nor the trade union movement match their rhetoric on the role of women in both politics and industrial matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The existing archaic industrial relations system that this legislation seeks to reform has traditionally given primacy to the interests of full-time adult males. As I have said, the trade union movement is dominated by full-time adult males. Women are very poorly represented in trade union hierarchies. Of course, unions negotiate deals that are consistent with their own agenda—the agenda that has been set by those dominant males.

Another example of the way in which unions have neglected the circumstances of women in the work force is their resistance to the insertion of part-time provisions in awards. These part‐time provisions, of course, would be advantageous to female workers.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?
—Yes, how?

—Because there are a number of women who would like to work part-time. It would enable them, again, to blend work and family responsibilities. Women would like those provisions to be inserted in awards to give them that opportunity—and the trade union movement resists it. As I have said, the union movement has resisted those part-time provisions being inserted into awards. On those rare occasions where agreement has occurred for such provisions, the unions have hedged on quotas and the minimum and maximum hours of work. Again, of course, I come back to the example of the clothing factory.

PARA.BREAK: It is also worth noting that the awards which have been the last to make provision for part‐time work have been in those indus tries that are dominated by what might be described as the macho unions—unions in the transport and building sectors that desire to keep women out of their particular industries. So a direct consequence of this failure on the part of the trade union movement has been an increase in casual part-time employment.

SPEECH.PARA: In August 1988 casual part-time employment represented 12.8 per cent of the work force. By August 1995 that had risen to 17 per cent. Casual employment does not provide for pro rata benefits with regard to safety net provisions—and again that shows up the failure of the trade union movement in protecting females in the work force.

By contrast, permanent part-time employment, where there is some opportunity to have protections in the system, only increased from 6.5 per cent to 8.8 per cent over that seven-year period—a very modest increase compared with that very significant increase in unprotected casual employment. As a consequence of that, we find that marginalised groups, such as women, have no predictability as far as working hours are concerned, or access to sick leave, or access to maternity leave. Indeed, existing awards still contain substantial restrictions on non-casual part-time work.

That is the record under the trade union movement; that is the record under the previous Labor government. In marked contrast to that, the new Howard coalition government, through its workplace relations bill, will reverse that bias in the current system which favours casual work as against permanent or regular part-time work. The legislation will promote predictable hours and will allow for family responsibilities and child-care arrangements. It will also provide pro rata conditions for sick leave, carers leave and maternity leave. It will also enable a greater involvement of permanent part-time workers in the established work force. It will also offer the additional benefit of providing improved training and career opportunities for part-time workers.

So there is the contrast: the absolute failure of the trade union movement and the previous government with regard to part-time workers, who are predominantly females, as against what this government and its legislation offers. That needs to be considered very seriously.

Of course, another reason for the Labor Party's opposition to this legislation is that it likes to foster a mentality of dependence. Woe betide anyone suggesting that people can manage their own employment affairs. That is the attitude of the Labor Party, and we have heard it expressed in the debate today—`They cannot manage their own affairs.'

What sort of attitude is that towards mature adults? We let them manage most of the rest of their lives. We let them manage their financial affairs, their family affairs, their marriage and the bringing up of their children. But when it comes to work, the Labor Party does not believe that people can manage their own affairs. It does not accept that people are capable of making reasonable and fair arrangements with their employers.

However, I would refer back to what I said at the outset of my remarks. I gave the example of those females in the clothing factory who initiated changes and sought and obtained the agreement of their employer with regard to more appropriate working hours—and it was the union who came in and knocked that down. Do not tell me that people cannot manage their own workplace affairs. If they want to do that, they ought to have the choice of doing it, they ought to have the freedom to do it.

If people want someone to represent them in those affairs, they should also have the choice of doing that. If they want a trade union to represent them, they should have the right to do that. But if they do not want to be represented by a trade union, they should not be forced to be so represented against their will. If they want a solicitor or some other negotiator to represent them, they should have the right to choose that form of representation as well—and they also should have the right to choose, if they so wish, to do their own negotiations.

That is what this legislation offers people: that flexibility, that freedom and that choice, in marked contrast to the existing legislation. Of course, again, that is why this legislation is so important but why the trade union movement and its Labor apparatchiki oppose it. They know that the trade union movement will have to offer real service and real benefits to its members if it is to retain their interest and their support.

Let me put on the record some of the other benefits that this legislation—and it is legislation now, it has been introduced—offers to people. It offers a comprehensive safety net, and that is spelt out in the legislation. As far as the proposed Australian workplace agreements are concerned, there is a comprehensive safety net spelt out in the legislation, and of course there is also the continuation of awards that provide the optional safety net.

That safety net relates to allowances, penalty rates, loadings, the hours of work and time that work may be performed, annual and long service leave together with sick and bereavement leave, and also carers leave. There is also the legislated minimum for maternity, paternity and adoption leave, provision for public hospitals and redundancy pay. All of those safety net provisions are there in the legislation.

The legislation also provides, as a minimum condition, equal pay for equal work of equal value. In particular, the safety net provisions will emphasise meeting the needs of the low paid. There is protection in the legislation against unfair dismissal. Employers will be specifically prohibited from dismissing employees on the grounds of sex, marital status, family responsibilities or pregnancy.

The legislation also provides very severe penalties against employers who apply duress in relation to the making of Australian workplace agreements. Again, let there be no suggestion that employees will be forced into these agreements against their will. That is specifically proscribed in the legislation, and heavy penalties will apply.

As I said a few moments ago, one of the important parts of the legislation is giving workers the freedom to choose who will represent them in negotiating their workplace agreements—whether that be a union or some other consultant they might choose with expertise in the area or whether they choose to directly negotiate themselves. Again, that is a marked contrast to the present legislation and the record of the previous Labor government. Their employees had absolutely no choice; they were forced to be members of trade unions and it was only the trade union that was given the right to negotiate on their behalf.

Often employees were not just forced to join a trade union, but also forced to join a trade union when they would have perhaps preferred to join a different trade union. That is a very important choice that we will give them under this legislation. By removing the `conveniently belong' clause from the legislation and by allowing for de‐amalgamation of unions, we will allow the establishment of new unions, which will more directly and more effectively represent the interests of those particular workers who choose to have them established and choose to join them. That is a very important part of the legislation.

I come back to the issue of female workers. No woman has received equal pay under the existing system when the Industrial Relations Commission has made orders in regard to over‐award payments. That is another shortcoming of the existing system, which our legislation will overcome. Let it not be said that this legislation in any way threatens the standards that workers might attain. In particular, it does not threaten the standards that female workers might attain.

In the process of developing this legislation and bringing it into the parliament, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Peter Reith, has had several consultations with women's groups and has adopted several of their recommendations. He has made it clear to these groups that the door is very much open to suggestions. The women's groups themselves have acknowledged this. I wish to indicate some of the groups which the minister has consulted. This is by no means an exhaustive list. He has had meetings with the Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women, the National Pay Equity Coalition, the Women's Electoral Lobby, the Australian Non‐English Speaking Background Women's Association, the Women's Economic Think Tank and the Council for Equal Opportunity in Employment.

BREAK.PARA: It is worth noting that as a direct consequence of those meetings, Ms Eva Cox, the co‐convenor of the Women's Economic Think Tank in Sydney, only as recently as yesterday said, `full marks to Peter Reith' with regard to the degree of consultation that he has undertaken with women's groups in relation to this legislation. Again, women have been very much to the fore in terms of the drafting of this legislation.

It is worth contrasting the minister's determination to consult on this legislation with what happened under the previous government when at midnight it ratified ILO convention 158 on unfair dismissal without any consultation whatsoever and then incorporated that convention holus‐bolus into the 1993 legislation. As a result of that we know only too well that many employees—in particular, small businessmen—have been forced to pay out on bogus unfair dismissal claims. In addition, many people have been denied jobs as a result of the employment‐deterring nature of that system. That is a contrast between this government and the minister, Peter Reith, and his consultative process and the jackboot way in which the previous government operated by ratifying that ILO convention on unfair dismissals at midnight without any consultation whatsoever.

As part of their strategy to attempt to undermine this legislation, the opposition parties—not only the Labor Party, but the Greens and the Democrats—have referred this legislation to the Senate Economics References Committee, not the Senate Economics Legislation Committee that was set up for the very purpose of examining legislation. They bypassed that and sent it to the references committee. Professor Judith Sloan made some very pertinent comments about that in the Australian this morning. However, that is what they have done and that is the process which will now have to be publicised. There is absolutely no doubt at all that this reference is part of the delaying, filibustering tactics of the opposition parties on this legislation.

If we are to go through this process, the very least that the Labor Party ought to do, including the shadow minister for industrial relations, Mr McMullan, is make public the more than 200 amendments which Mr McMullan claims he has drafted for this legislation. He has only made a very few of them public. He claims he has more than 200 amendments. If he has, let us have them on the table, let us see them and let us have them before this committee so that they can be considered as well as the proposals of the government.

If we are going to have this process whereby Senator Ferguson, Senator Crane and I, as well as opposition senators, are going to be shunted all over Australia to hear supposed evidence on this legislation following the receipt of written submissions—

TALK.START.PARA: —Consult. He is talking about consulting.

—At least those people who are making submissions to the committee in writing and who then want to appear to give verbal evidence ought to have the right to examine those amendments, as well as examining the government's legislation, and then express an opinion on the impact of those amendments as well as on the government's legislation. If the committee process is to operate properly and effectively, then that ought to be the way it works. I call on Mr McMullan to release all of those amendments, let the committee have them and let those who are making submissions to the committee see them and make submissions on those amendments as well as on the legislation.
—What is he hiding?

—Exactly. What is he hiding? They ought to be provided to us now. Again, the failure to do that simply highlights that all the Labor Party is doing in regard to this legislation is a filibustering exercise to seek to undermine it. What is being done through that committee contrasts markedly with the way we, when in opposition, treated their so‐called Industrial Relations Reform Bill of 1993. We opposed a substantial part of that quite bitterly because we knew that, instead of taking industrial relations into the 21st century, it was returning it to the 19th century. Despite that, we dealt with it constructively through relatively brief committee hearings and we did not conduct this filibustering exercise all over Australia.

BREAK.PARA: That committee examined that legislation with respect to three terms of reference only, compared with the 15 terms of reference that the present opposition parties have put before the Senate Economic References Committee. That is a clear indication that, when in opposition, we dealt constructively with legislation; the present opposition is dealing destructively with legislation. That simply shows that the Labor Party is not genuine as far as this legislation is concerned. Let me draw my remarks to a close by quoting a former President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, a former Prime Minister of this country and Labor Party leader, in relation to the goals of this legislation. What he said late in May was:

. . . for its part, the trade union movement must recognise . . . the right of an employer and an employee, freely, to enter into individual contracts underpinned by an independently determined safety net.

That is a clear political message to the Labor Party to face the realities of the 1990s, yet it is the message that the present Labor Party wants to ignore. It is the message that has been given to them by one of their former leaders, yet they clearly want to ignore that message.

The workplace relations bill put forward by this government offers exactly that opportunity, as it also offers a wide range of opportunities to employers and employees to get together and negotiate the most appropriate terms and conditions of work, subject to that independently determined safety net, so that they can enjoy the shared benefits of their particular enterprise, recognising that together they can make an enterprise successful and that they should share the success of that enterprise. They should get rid of the `us and them' mentality that for so long has been fostered by the trade union movement, the Labor Party and our current archaic industrial relations system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Before Senator Mackay rises, it has been drawn to my attention that Senator Conroy seems to be eating or chewing something in the chamber. It has long been held that eating, chewing—even Strepsils—or smoking is contrary to good parliamentary conduct and I suggest you direct him to leave the chamber or swallow it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition said during the election, `Under a Howard government you will not be worse off.' You certainly will if you happen to be a woman. It may come as a shock to some of those opposite that in 1994 women made up 43 per cent of the paid work force and that 52 per cent of married women were in paid work. More than ever, women are combining work and raising families. This government continues to fail the women of Australia and is doing so yet again with this industrial relations bill. It is failing them through changes to the award system and with its workplace agreements. It is failing them in terms of equal pay. It is failing them by not protecting part‐time and casual work provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: An important aspect of the current award system is the safety net, a set of employment conditions contained in the awards. The government is proposing to strip the industrial commission of its power to arbitrate above a basic minimum standard. Many issues affecting women will be removed from awards. These include, to name a few, equal employment opportunity and workplace harassment, minimum breaks between shifts, occupational health and safety, paid maternity leave, and so on.

The government also plans to abolish paid rates awards, which set actual rates of pay as an alternative to over‐award payments. Paid rates awards apply particularly in the public sector and their abolition will greatly affect nurses, teachers, community sector workers and lower and middle‐ranking public servants—in other words, predominantly women.

Looking at state awards: 54 per cent of female employees are covered by state awards. This legislation will make it harder, if not virtually impossible, to move to a federal award. This will severely disadvantage workers in female dominated industries traditionally covered by state awards, such as clerical and retail areas and the hospitality, health and community services industries.

Federal awards and agreements will be overridden by state employment agreements. Women starting new jobs in areas otherwise covered by awards and agreements—even women in existing jobs—will be required to work under state enterprise agreements. In some states, including my state, Tasmania, these have substantially reduced minimum conditions. These women workers will be worse off.

What about workplace agreements? An Australian workplace agreement as proposed by this government is a secret document. It must be signed by each employee. The agreements are not supposed to go below the minimum entitlements but it is up to the individual worker to ensure that they do not. They must know in detail all their award entitlements. These workplace agreements can be made before the employee starts work. You do not have to be too bright to work out that you have to sign the agreement or you do not get the job.

Let us look at the effects on some real people. Christine is a prospective Tasmanian worker. Her situation is typical. Work is going at a new glass manufacturing firm. Christine needs a job and has the required skills. She is lucky, luckier than most unemployed Tasmanians, and gets offered a job. But the job is dependent upon her signing a workplace agreement. She reads it and it sounds okay. She cannot honestly say that she understands it, but she does not have a choice. If she wants to get employment, she has to sign.

This government plans to make certified agreements, that is, the collective agreements between unions and employers, subject to those new objects of the act which talk about so-called flexibility and productivity—a euphemism if ever I have heard one. The effect of this on women would be to encourage agreements which undermine award conditions such as hours of work and penalty rates. The government intends to drop the current requirement that all unions at a workplace negotiate as a single bargaining unit. So in a workplace where the women employees are in a minority union, for example, a clerk in a motor repair shop, they are in a very vulnerable position indeed.

An example of the case in point: Meredith works as the sole office worker in a smash repair firm. The seven male employees have thrashed out an enterprise agreement with the boss. It suits them and their work conditions. It does not suit Meredith and her work conditions. What can she do? Nothing.

Let us look at equal pay. Women already lag significantly behind men in terms of over‐award payments. The position of women relative to that of men in terms of total remuneration will get worse. Why? Discrimination on the basis of gender will be untrammelled under this bill.

Currently, women earn only 54 per cent of the over‐award payments made to men. The federal Labor government acted on this obvious inequity and in 1994 introduced new equal remuneration provisions. Using these provisions, unions have had major successes in negotiating the removal of clearly discriminatory over‐award payments, especially for women process workers in the manufacturing industry.

The Industrial Relations Commission will lose its power to redress discrimination in over‐award payments. Employers will now be able to discriminate on the basis of sex. The notion of equal pay for equal work will apply to only the minimum basic award. It will not apply to over‐award payments.

Prior to the election, the coalition pledged its support for equal pay. With its hand on its heart it said, `Trust us, we are here to help you.' The federal Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) now wants to repeal the equal pay provisions in the Industrial Relations Act—a massive step backwards would be a complete understatement. Mr Reith claims that there is already adequate jurisdiction in the area of equal pay.

The coalition proposes that equal pay will be adequately enforced by the 1969 and 1972 equal pay test case principles, the Australian workplace agreements and certified agreements having equal pay for work of equal value as a minimum standard, and the federal Sex Discrimination Act 1984. There are obviously problems with this proposal. These three areas of jurisdiction are clearly inadequate to redress the remaining discrimination in women's wage rates.

Let us have a look at the case of Roberta. Roberta knows that the workplace agreement that she has signed breaches the equal pay standard. When she asks what she can do about it, she is informed that she can take her concerns to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. She may have to wait for up to two years to then go through a complex and daunting process. So what does she do? She gives up and cops the agreement.

The Industrial Relations Commission is the appropriate body for dealing with these pay related issues. It has the knowledge and the accessibility to give the provisions clout. The proof of the pudding is in the eating. Just look for yourselves at the successful settlements of claims under these provisions so far.

Let us have a look at part-time work. The Industrial Relations Commission will be stopped from setting maximum or minimum hours of work for regular part-time employees. Women form the bulk of casual and part-time workers—75 per cent, in fact. Of working women, 41 per cent work part time. These workers need a regular minimum income to meet family commitments. In the interests of the euphemistic flexibility, the government is proposing to remove all restrictions on part-time work. This will create great uncertainty for these workers, particularly women, and will mean a reduction in wages.

Current award provisions provide for a minimum number of hours of work per week for part-time workers in order to ensure that they are given reasonable work opportunities and income. Consistency in rostering arrangements for part-time workers with family responsibilities is absolutely vital. The removal of requirements for a set number of hours and notice in advance will have a disastrous impact on the many women who are currently juggling work around creche and school hours.

Consider this Tasmanian case: John and Mary Smith have two small children. John works full-time as a driveway attendant. His hours are variable. Mary works part time as a shop assistant. She has been able to arrange her child care around her reasonably consistent hours of work. She and John are reliant on her contribution to the household budget. Under this legislation, Mary will have no idea from week to week when she will be working, or if, in fact, she can expect to work at all. Her capacity to plan her children's care and to budget has disappeared.

Under the new arrangements, employers can arbitrarily pare back an employee's hours one week to virtually nil and increase them dramatically the next week, making it impossible to budget or to organise family commitments around work. Flexible? Sure. Fair? I do not think so. Family friendly? Definitely not.

Over the past weeks, literally dozens of people have contacted by electorate office—and I assume the same for my colleagues—expressing their concern about changes to industrial relations and how it will affect them. Many of them have been women, women like those I have mentioned—Mary, Roberta and Meredith. For this side of the chamber, this legislation strikes at the very heart of our belief in principles of social justice. We believe this legislation is a blatant betrayal of the working women of Australia who voted for the coalition. Let me tell you, they will not forget it when they get a chance to vote again in 1999.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the motion moved by Senator Jacinta Collins, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—

(a) notes the overwhelming Australian and overseas evidence that the majority of Australian workers will be disadvantaged by the Government's proposals to reform Australia's industrial relations system; and

(b) condemns the Government for continually failing to acknowledge women's concerns in particular, whilst defending the `rock solid' guarantee of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that no worker will be worse off.

This is not an area in which I have participated in the Senate before. I want to start my speech by putting into context why I most probably feel so strongly about these reforms. Some time ago, former Senator Richardson asked me—and I do not suppose we are supposed to reveal conversations held outside in the corridor—`How did the New South Wales Right ever miss you when you were at university? Why didn't we get you?' I did not have time to fully explain to former Senator Richardson why the New South Wales Right never got me.

They never got me because I was politicised as an 11‐year‐old when my mother, who was a single mother at the time, had to work full time. She came home one night in tears. She was crying because she worked in a hotel and did not want to join a union. The union had said that they would black ban the hotel if she did not join. She was put between a rock and a hard place: she was either not going to have a job, with a child she had to rear on her own, or she was going to have to join the union. That is not social justice.

How can Senator Mackay come in here and talk about social justice when my mother was forced to join a union because her employer, the hotel she was working at, was not going to be supplied with grog unless she joined the union? There were a lot of women who worked with my mother who were not going to join the union. The employer finally paid their union fees so she could get the beer, grog, cigarettes and everything else delivered to her hotel because she was going to be black banned.

That was the major issue that politicised me. I decided from then on I would never ever be forced to join a union. I would go to the wall, I would go to gaol, I would do anything not to join a union. I could not see what benefit my mother was getting. She was working for an employer who was incredibly compassionate. In fact, she was working for a long distant relative by marriage of Senator Parer who was one of the most compassionate employers. None of her workers wanted to join a union yet they were forced to do so.

A bit further down the track, when I was at Monash University, the problems for women in particular when they are forced to join a union were reinforced for me. I happened to be deputy warden of a halls of residence at a time when there was a cleaners strike. The general staff of the university went on strike over some issue. We had students who were unable to get food because we could not get food delivered. There were all sorts of things. There were lots of inconveniences.

The thing that concerned me most was when the woman who used to clean my apartment came to me in tears and said, `I hope you didn't see me picketing outside the university.' I said that I had not seen her. She said, `I didn't want to picket. I chose to go at 5 a.m. because I was rung up and told that if I did not picket my kids would not find their way home from school.'

Where is the social justice in that, Senator Mackay? Where is the social justice in a woman being threatened to picket? We can stand here and talk about employers who are unfair, who have done things that are not appropriate—and we all know that that occurs—but I have just given examples, and I am sure other colleagues can give example after example, where unions have not played the game properly either. There would be examples where they have not behaved appropriately, where they have abused their privileges, where they have abused their membership.

We can find fault on both sides. We are prepared to stand up here and agree that there are employers who have not always done the right thing, but I do not hear the other side getting up and saying that unions have not always done the right thing. Not one speaker on the other side has said that. It is as though the unions are always right, always do the right thing, always do things for the social justice system.

I see someone on the other side shaking his head. He most probably has examples of where they have not actually performed their duty but in fact done a disservice to their members. That is one of the positions I am coming from. That issue most probably continued to cement my politicisation towards the Liberal side of politics because I could not see women, in particular, being served very well by unions in either of those instances.

The other side is saying the world will fall in because of this workplace relations bill. That is not the case. There are protections, there are safeguards in place which mean we will have a more productive society. I have family who run small businesses and who now will not employ people because of the unfair dismissal law—and do not raise your eyebrows! They prefer not to increase production because it is too hard to get rid of somebody.

Only the other day I was talking to an organisation in Melbourne which wrote to me because somebody had engraved their name and various other bits and bobs all over the furniture in its building. It has cost that organisation something like $80,000 in legal fees to finally dismiss this person, who continued to engrave all over the office furniture, doors and all sorts of other pieces around its office.

You can raise your eyebrows about that but lots of people would be better off if employers were in a position to employ them. They are not employing them now. Business after business comes to us and says that they are not putting people on. The pharmacist down the road from me said, `I am not going to put anybody on because if they are hopeless I can't get rid of them.' So really they are saying that they will not create jobs.

Who have the unions been protecting? They have not protected the three quarters of a million people who are presently unemployed. I have not heard one speaker from the other side talk about all the people who are unemployed because unions have the sorts of policies that they have and because of the sorts of industrial relations rules that exist. Not one person on the other side has talked about rights and social justice for the unemployed—not one. Many are unemployed because of the current union inability to accept that the unfair dismissal laws in particular discourage employers from employing people.

Under this bill workers will be better off, despite what the Labor Party says. They will be recognised and respected. They will not be disadvantaged in the way Senator Jacinta Collins asserts in her notice of motion. The bill respects and values the fact that the Australian work force is diverse. It will open up the industrial relations system to workers who traditionally have been neglected by the system, and that includes women.

One of the primary ways this will be done is by focusing on individual employers and employees rather than on traditional industrial relations institutions. Currently, unions can enter into an agreement with an employer and have it certified by the commission without even getting the support of the employees who will be affected. The commission should look into the agreement and make sure that workers are not disadvantaged but, in practice, the commission just takes the union's word that they are not.

What is implemented is what is best for the union rather than what is best for the worker. In many cases what is implemented is what is best for male unionists without taking into account what is best for the female members of a union. The coalition wants to reverse that situation. We want deals negotiated that will not leave workers worse off, and we want deals negotiated without the unions unnecessarily influencing the outcome.

I want to go through some of the things that various speakers have said. Senator Jacinta Collins talked about the exploitation of outworkers under a deregulated labour market. Labor has been in power for 13 years. Some of you might say that this issue is about federal and state awards, but it was not a Labor member of the Senate who decided to initiate a Senate inquiry into outworkers. If Labor members were so concerned about this matter, why didn't they initiate such an inquiry? For Senator Collins to talk about the exploitation of outworkers when Labor has been in power for 13 years reflects more on Senator Collins than on the legislation.

Senator Margetts said that you cannot judge an industrial relations system by the behaviour of a good employer. I think you could argue that you cannot judge an industrial relations system by what a good union does either. As I have pointed out before, there are situations in which unions do not always work in the best interests of individual members. Unions have not worked effectively to protect the rights of workers. I will talk about that more in a moment when I talk about part‐ time work and what has happened in that area.

Senator Childs said that the legislation was social Darwinism—the strong prosper and the weak suffer—and was going back to dinosaurs. He talked about people working in factories whose first language was not English and how disadvantaged they would be. I can only think that he is talking about one of two possible situations, the first of which is where there is a non‐union certified agreement, the terms of which will have been approved by the commission.

The second is where there is an Australian workplace agreement. This agreement will not have been vetted by the commission—I admit that—but the worker, if they so choose, can be a member of a union and have a union person negotiate on their behalf. If the worker is not satisfied or if there be some breach of the Australian workplace agreement, they have access to the employment advocate. This will be a specialist advisory body that will give advice and pay legal fees if the employer does not meet minimum standards.

The bill enables the employment advocate's advice and assistance function to be contracted out in accordance with suitable funding and accountability arrangements. One option which has been given close consideration is partially contracting out some functions of the advocate to non‐government community organisations. Workers who have been traditionally marginalised, such as women from non‐English speaking backgrounds, may feel more comfortable seeking help from community based organisations. They will have access to both those sorts of organisations and an employment advocate to deal with their concerns.

When Senator Mackay was speaking it appeared as though the only right workers had was to go to the equal opportunities or human rights commission and wait two years. When she was talking about Christine, Roberta, Mr and Mrs Smith and the other few inhabitants of Tasmania that she knows by name, Senator Mackay made no mention of the fact that if they had an Australian workplace agreement they had the right to go to an employment advocate. Labor avoids telling all the story. They like to run around spreading myths, stirring up anxiety and peddling untruths in order to take away from the debate on the issues.

For instance, they do not say how unions could assist in this exercise. No doubt there are some unions and some unionists who will participate. They will have to because the union movement is now haemorrhaging. Obviously, people do not feel that the unions are representing them because membership is dropping. Campaigns are running here and there to increase union membership.

Why are people leaving the unions? Because they do not think the unions are doing the right job by them. Hopefully the unions will lift their game and, under the new regime, represent those who choose to join a union. And it will be by choice. That is the important thing. There will be the choice to join a union or not to join a union. Hopefully, the union will, in fact, participate in what we believe will be a much more effective workplace and environment, both for workers and employers.

Senator Jacinta Collins went on about the motion disadvantaging women. The current system has disadvantaged women enormously. What has happened is employers are not prepared to put on people on full‐time awards. The unions have not encouraged permanent part-time work, and what that has done is force people into casual employment where they do not have the benefits of sick leave and other protections. They have been forced into casual work.

Who are those people who have been forced into casual work? Mainly women. But the unions do not worry about that. As long as its union membership is protected, it does not worry about the people who have been forced out into casual work—people who cannot get permanent part-time work or permanent full-time work. As long as its union members' jobs are protected—especially those who are in the organisational section of the union—it does not worry about social justice for, in particular, those women who have been forced into part-time work.

Even though the unions have resisted part-time work, there has been a large growth in part-time work over the last few years. Part-time employment has increased from 6.5 per cent of employees in August 1988 to 8.8 per cent in August 1995, and casual part-time employment has increased from 12.8 per cent to 17 per cent of employees over the same period. What people are saying is that they want part-time employment. Many of them would prefer permanent part-time employment so that they can have access to sick leave and the other benefits, but, of course, as I said, very few of the unions have been advocates for that and have pushed for that.

The industrial relations system in this country has traditionally favoured the interests of full‐time adult males. It is a result of the position that unions and the previous government played in the system and, as I said, the fact that the majority of unions have been dominated by full‐time adult males.

Under the workplace relations bill, compulsory unionism will be outlawed, which will result in agreements only being certified by the commission if they have the support of the majority of the work force. This will mean that unions will do what the workers want rather than telling workers what they want. The unions will be the workers' agents, as they should be.

I look forward to participating further in the debate as the legislation comes forward. I look forward to seeing more and more articles like the one that appeared yesterday. Senator Ferguson talked about an article by Des Fooks in the Canberra Times on Wednesday. He wrote at length about the importance of the industrial relations bill and the impact it will have on training and training for young people. In particular, again, this will affect women who want to increase their training or particular women who want to re-enter the work force. As he said, the bill makes sense for trainees. It will, in fact, be a positive for women. There will be more and more people coming out telling about the advantages, not only for women but for workers in particular.

The reforms in the bill are a response to the community's needs and demands that action can be taken to create more jobs, train young people, recognise the value of women workers and achieve a higher standard of living for workers and their families. The crucial point for all workers, particularly women workers, is that all work agreements cannot lead to employees being paid less than they would get under the award. In other words, workers will be better off under the new system.

In conclusion, the workplace relations bill is a bill for all Australian workers and one which will see them better off and in control of their own destiny. It is a bill about freedom of choice, and I emphasise that. I started my comments on that note and I end on the note that it is about freedom of choice, better working conditions and recognition of the value of each individual worker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that many thousands of Australian workers and their families will be disadvantaged by the actions of this coalition government. There is no doubt that the promise made so solemnly by the then Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, that no worker would be worse off was a false and deceitful promise. It was not a hallowed undertaking; it was a hollow promise.

SPEECH.PARA: We now see the manic drive by the coalition government to cut expenditure, and that is producing situations where people are going to become—and are becoming—worse off because they are losing their jobs. Massive cutbacks to occur in the Public Service will result in the retrenchment of many hundreds of workers. The closure of CES offices and Department of Social Security offices throughout the country will not only affect the workers directly employed in those organisations but have a consequential impact upon those people out there in the community who rely upon the services of the CES and the Department of Social Security in looking for work and in other social security areas.

We will have the workplace relations bill before the Senate in the next session, following its consideration by the Senate economics committee. This bill is nothing more than an ideologically motivated attack upon workers in this country and their representative organisations. This is the culmination of the Prime Minister's long desire, now an obsession, to reform—the words he used—the labour market. But there is nothing reforming about this bill. This, in fact, will turn back the clock many years in industrial relations and in industrial protection for workers in this country.

It is clear from the coalition's policy document that they took to the last election, misnamed `Better pay for better work'. In the very title there is the inference that Australian workers do not work hard enough or well enough. You have to go to only the second paragraph of the introduction on page 1 to find the first reference to the trade union movement. That is what this bill is about. It is about attempting to destroy or dismantle the trade union movement.

When you read the Governor-General's speech, which was presented on behalf of the government at the opening of parliament, again right up there in lights at the very start of the speech is all this rhetoric about reform of the labour market. Consequently, there are attacks upon the trade union movement, because the coalition has this obsessional belief that the trade union movement is an impediment to reform in the labour market.

In order to have some grasp of what is in store for workers in this country under this bill, you need to first of all have a look at a bit of history to see where the coalition government is coming from. What we have seen in the bill and what we have heard in the speeches from the government members this evening is what we have heard for years and years. They are the sorts of insults and attacks upon trade unions and upon trade union leaders. That is essentially the extent of the contributions they make to any rational debate about industrial relations in this country. Get stuck into the union officials. Get stuck into the union officials who happen to be members of parliament. Make snide remarks, like Senator Alston did today and like Senator Chapman has done, that somehow these people are not worthy of even being called workers or are not worthy of even becoming members of parliament because they are trade union officials. How terrible! They say they have never lived in the real world.

They do not seem to consider people like Senator Alston, Senator Hill and Senator Vanstone, who are members of that great trade union—the legal profession, the Law Society, which sets its charges. There is a scale of fees for lawyers, a minimum set, and they charge well over it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Outrageous, they are.

—Outrageous. You are right, Senator Campbell. Then there are those other representatives, like Senator Herron and Senator Woods, of the trade union, the Australian Medical Association. Then we have Senator Crane here tonight.
—What about the farmers?

—That is right. What about the farmers? What about the farmers union of Western Australia? You do not hear us over here on this side attacking the motives or the integrity of members of the government because they happen to have had some previous professional career and have been members of a representative organisation. Nevertheless, according to you over here we have us trade union officials who do not represent anybody.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that people like Senator Collins and myself are very proud of the fact that we came from the trade union movement. I am proud of the fact that before I went into the trade union movement I worked in the oil industry, the building industry, the liquor industry and in the rural sector. When I was working for the trade union movement, I travelled the length and breadth of this country. We talked to workers and represented workers because that was our job.

Let's look at the history. The history of the coalition whilst it was in opposition was what? It was to oppose every single national wage increase that was ever sought, except for the last two. The now Treasurer (Mr Costello) in his previous career as a barrister represented the National Farmers Federation on a number of occasions in cases that I was involved in—and Senator Crane knows this full well—and opposed national wage increases for shearers and other rural workers time and time again, opposed them getting superannuation. Then you have the hide to come in here and say to us that you are on about protecting low paid workers, that you are on about giving them freedom of choice.

The fact of the matter is that during that same period, the Hawke and Keating government—whilst the coalition were out there opposing national wage increases, opposing other improvements such as superannuation and other social wage benefits, the introduction of paternity and maternity leave—the Labor government was involved in improving the lot of ordinary working Australians: improving their real wages.

It is totally incorrect, as a number of speakers in the coalition have said, to say that real wages declined during the Hawke and Keating years. Real wages, in fact, increased during that period. They increased quite substantially. Real wages, in terms of real average weekly earnings for full-time adults, increased by 7.3 per cent over the 13 years of the Labor government. Real average weekly ordinary time earnings for full-time adults increased by 5.9 per cent.

So it is about time speakers in the coalition got their facts straight. Those increases do not even include the additional benefits that came through in terms of superannuation, ratcheting up to the equivalent of nine per cent by the year 2000. Where was the then opposition, the now government, when all of this was happening? They were busy opposing all of these improvements and attacking trade union leaders.

Let us turn to the evidence from overseas. It is quite clear that the coalition is still locked into Thatcherism and Reaganism in terms of their approach to industrial relations. During the Reagan years in the United States between 1980 and 1988, the minimum wage was frozen—frozen for eight years. Each time there was an attempt to increase it, it was vetoed. The only reason any increases in the minimum wage have come about is essentially through the actions of the Democratic Party and President Clinton. In England, under Prime Minister Thatcher, virtually the entire industrial north of England was destroyed in terms of its capacity to deliver jobs for people in those regions and growth for the economy.

Given the small amount of time I have left, I would like to concentrate on one or two issues relating to the workplace relations bill. The coalition government says that it is going to maintain minimum standards in awards. But what it is doing is actually legislating to remove a huge range of conditions that currently apply in minimum rates awards. Such things as superannuation will no longer be a requirement—by legislation.

These are conditions that have been negotiated, agreed and put into awards, or have been arbitrated by the commission and put into awards in this country. But under your legislation, they will be removed. Things such as superannuation; meal breaks; training; travelling, transport and fare allowances; accident pay; time and wage records; and right of entry will be removed. There is a long list of them. As Senator Crane would know, pick up any award of the Industrial Relations Commission and you will see those things enshrined in minimum rates awards. They have been regarded as entitlements for years.

The fact of the matter is that once you remove them by legislation and you seek to move to a system of either workplace agreements or non-union based enterprise agreements, the balance is tilted and those conditions will disappear very quickly. When the employee fronts up for the job and is presented with the contract of employment, prepared by some industrial consultant on behalf of the employer, it will not have those conditions in it. The story will be: if you do not agree to that, you do not get the job. (Time expired)
